placeMetadata.name: Lingaraj Temple

sources.snippet: In the 1940s, Bhubaneswar had devolved into an obscure centre of pilgrimage â€“ a few devotees used to visit the Lingaraj Temple. Bhubaneswar had a rich history dating back to the Kalinga War of 261 BC and bore the imprints of flourishing Jain and Buddhist culture. The German historian Herman Kulke had baptized Bhubaneswar as â€œthe oldest Indian capital with the longest uninterrupted history.
sources.shortName: Unwelcoming Spaces: How the Architectural Vision for Bhubaneswar Has Blurred Over 75 Years

placeMetadata.description: Ancient Hindu temple compound featuring carved stone towers, courtyards & numerous shrines.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Lingaraj Temple, situated in Bhubaneswar, is a renowned Hindu temple devoted to Lord Shiva. It holds great historical and cultural significance and is known for its distinctive Kalinga-style architecture. The temple complex features intricately carved stone towers, courtyards, and numerous shrines. According to ancient inscriptions and Sanskrit treatises, the temple is at the center of a sacred area surrounded by other significant temples and mango groves.
placeMetadata.address: Lingaraj Temple Rd, Lingaraj Nagar, Old Town, Bhubaneswar, Odisha 751002, India

reviews.reviewText: Visiting the temple was truly a remarkable experience, filled with a sense of peace and spirituality. The intricate architecture and the detailed carvings are absolutely breathtaking, showcasing exquisite craftsmanship. It was fascinating to witness the rituals and ceremonies performed with such devotion and precision. The atmosphere surrounding the temple creates a feeling of serenity, allowing for moments of introspection. Overall, a visit to this temple is a must for anyone seeking a glimpse into the rich cultural heritage.

Lingaraj Temple is one of the most ancient and magnificent temples Iâ€™ve visited. The architecture is truly stunning, showcasing intricate carvings and a deep sense of devotion. I was fortunate to have a peaceful darshan and even got to touch the sacred Shivling, which felt spiritually powerful. Inside the complex, there are many smaller temples, each beautifully designed and adding to the divine atmosphere. One of the best parts is that mobile phones are not allowed inside, which keeps the environment calm and respectful. However, thereâ€™s a dedicated viewpoint outside where visitors can take selfies and videos, which is a thoughtful addition. Overall, itâ€™s a must-visit spiritual destination in Bhubaneswar.

I visited the ancient temple complex after a period of 36 years. Comparing to that experience it has become far more organised and disciplined. Surroundings are kept very neat and clean. Security beefed up. I saw a very pleasant expressions on the faces of Devotees, coming out of the main shrine. But what made me most surprised was that the temple complex was kept in a heritage vibe. You would see it in through our age old prism and can not believe that you were within the beautiful and modern capital city of Bhubaneswar.

while i was travelling to Kolkata, i stood up in Bhubaneswar for 9 hours. In that meantime, i started exploring the old town by walk.  it was kinda peaceful and i loved the environment there people busy with their chores, kids playingâ¤ï¸ i went through Lingaraj temple, no phones allowed. in temple, there are several other temples too. so i recommend people to explore each and every temple. i had a wonderful experience to learn about their culture and food habits. people are so friendly and welcoming.

Lingaraj Temple in Bhubaneswar is a famous and beautiful temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is very old and has amazing stone carvings.The temple complex, sprawling across a large courtyard, includes numerous smaller shrines and is a prime example of Kalinga architecture. Daily rituals and festivals draw large crowds, and while prasad (offering) is served, it often involves a nominal fee for the meal. Non-Hindus have limited access to the inner sanctum, but can admire the exterior architecture from a designated platform

Can't explain the architecture of this temple! It's one of the greatest temples, I have ever visited in my life. The height of the temple and the small - small idols of the gods on that height can't anyone think of it.

data.title: The 33 most romantic places in Bhubaneswar

placeMetadata.name: Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves

sources.snippet: Lingaraja Temple: Start your exploration of Bhubaneswar's historical and cultural attractions with a visit to the magnificent Lingaraja Temple. This ancient temple, dedicated to Lord Shiva, is a masterpiece of Kalinga architecture. Marvel at its towering spire, intricately carved sculptures, and sacred rituals that take place within its premises.
sources.shortName: Best Place for Couples in Bhubaneswar! - Blogs

sources.snippet: Situated a few miles away from Bhubaneswar, the Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are rock cut caves believed to have been carved out by Jain monks. The caves sit adjacent to each other and have inscriptions written all over its walls. Within the two caves, there are many small caves that have important stone carvings, footprints, and sculptures.
sources.shortName: The 15 Most Iconic Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: For a quick getaway, discover the bhubaneswar nearby places offering a blend of wildlife, pilgrimage, and natural beauty. The Nandankanan Zoological Park captivates with its rare white tigers and enthralling safaris. A day trip to the sun-kissed beaches of Puri or the tranquil waters of Chilika Lake will rejuvenate your senses.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Must-Visit Attractions in Bhubaneswar for Couples!

sources.snippet: Next, head to the Khandagiri and Udayagiri Caves, a set of ancient rock-cut caves that offer a glimpse into the regionâ€™s history. These caves date back to the 2nd century BCE and were once inhabited by Jain monks. As you explore the caves, you can admire the fascinating carvings and inscriptions.
sources.siteName: Guide Tour Explore Tourist places India
sources.shortName: 16 Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: Khandagiri caves are popularly and locally known as the Cuttack Caves. The artificial cave is popular with couples because they can silently sneak into the caves and have their romantic time together. The beautiful cave surrounds itself with greeneries and nature making it perfect romance locus.

The Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are archaeologically, historically, and religiously significant caves which are one of the eminent tourist sites in the city of Odisha. The majority of these caves are thought to have been used by Jain monks as living places during King Kharavela's rule.
sources.shortName: Tourist Places & Top Things to Do in 2025

sources.snippet: Khandagiri and Udayagiri Caves offer a surreal setting for couples who appreciate history and art. Exploring the ancient caves, hand in hand, and marveling at the intricate carvings can evoke a sense of shared wonder, weaving romantic moments into the tapestry of time.
sources.shortName: BEST PLACES TO VISIT IN BHUBANESWAR FOR COUPLES | GUIDE | by ontravelx

sources.snippet: Credits: Phadke09, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons. One of the twin caves of Bhubaneswar is the Udayagiri Caves. With 18 existing caves, it stands tall with historically significant ancient sculptures and reliefs.
sources.shortName: 47 Best Tourist Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar 2024

placeMetadata.description: Elaborately carved cave dwellings dating to the 1st c. BCE, topped by an 18th-c. CE Jain temple.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled just 6 kilometers from the vibrant city of Bhubaneshwar, the Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are a treasure trove of ancient history, dating back to the 1st century BCE. These intricately carved cave dwellings served as homes for Jain ascetics and offer a unique glimpse into their simple yet profound lifestyle.
placeMetadata.address: 7Q7M+2V7, Khandagiri, Bhubaneswar, Odisha 751030, India

reviews.reviewText: Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are really amazing to visit. These ancient caves are beautifully carved and have a lot of history connected to Jain monks. The stone carvings are worth seeing, and some caves also give you a glimpse of meditation cells used in old times. The view from the top is also nice and peaceful. Best time to visit is in the evening or early morning when itâ€™s not too hot.

Situated on the outskirts of a bustling city in Odisha, this ancient site is a remarkable blend of history, spirituality, and nature. Carved into solid rock, the twin hill structures hold centuries-old caves that once served as dwellings and meditation chambers for monks. These rock-cut marvels are not just architectural wonders but also sacred spaces that echo the deep roots of Jainism and its teachings in the region.

The caves are adorned with intricate carvings, inscriptions, and symbolic motifs that reflect the simplicity and discipline of monastic life. Each chamber tells a silent tale of devotion, enlightenment, and the human quest for inner peace. The cool interiors, despite the surrounding heat, offer a calming and reflective environment, inviting visitors to pause and connect with a timeless past.

The surrounding landscape adds to the charm â€” lush greenery, chirping birds, and panoramic views of the city from the hilltops create a perfect blend of history and natural beauty. Climbing the stone steps to explore each cave is like walking through the pages of a living history book. The serenity of the place makes it a favorite for spiritual seekers, historians, and nature lovers alike.

What truly sets this site apart is its silent endurance through the ages. It continues to inspire with its blend of art, faith, and resilience. Whether it's a quiet sunrise visit or a thoughtful exploration of the caves, the experience leaves one with a deep appreciation for Odishaâ€™s ancient legacy and the peaceful strength of its spiritual traditions.

The Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves, carved in the 1st century BCE by King Kharavela of the Mahameghavahana dynasty, served as residential and meditative retreats for Jain monks and feature the famous Hathigumpha inscription detailing the kingâ€™s reign.

These caves are of immense historical and religious importance, showcasing early Jain art, rock-cut architecture, and the cultural richness of ancient Kalinga.

Today, they are preserved as heritage monuments and attract pilgrims, historians, and tourists as a symbol of Odishaâ€™s spiritual and archaeological legacy.

A wonderful blend of history and nature! Visited Udayagiri Caves with family and kids â€” the ancient rock-cut caves were fascinating and full of stories. The carvings are beautiful, and the peaceful surroundings made it a perfect spot for a relaxed and educational outing. Great place for kids to explore and learn!

The caves are an absolute historical wonder. The way they are cut and sculpted is mesmerizing. Children under 15 yrs are free and it's 25per person. The udayagiri caves have less climbing but Khandagiri you have to climb a lot of stairs we didn't go to Khandagiri. It's recommended to come in the morning as it's very hot at noon. It has a ramp to get to one of the top parts of the caves .

1. Itâ€™s an archaeological and historical site. Entry ticket is only â‚¹20.
2. There are a total of 18 ancient caves, mainly used by Jain ascetics.
3. It's a nice and peaceful place to visit for history lovers. The site is divided into two hills: Udayagiri and Khandagiri, and both can be visited with a single ticket.
4. Thereâ€™s a beautiful temple located on top of Khandagiri hill.
5. A great place for learning history, taking photos, and enjoying light trekking.

It was a lovely experience. I went there with my mom and sister. Going up to the hill tops was pretty exhausting but we had fun. Then view from Khandgiri top was just amazingðŸ˜  The temple on Udaygiri was beautiful too. You will enjoy the hiking part inspite of hard hiking. Shere are budget friendly shops at the bottom of those hills where you can get food of drinks at regular price.
Ticket prices were Rs.25 per Indian person, and 300 per person for foreigners only.
If you have severe injury in legs or joint pain then avoid these. Because even the stairs are too steep.

Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are amazing historical sites with beautiful carvings and ancient caves. The place is peaceful and great for exploring, offering a fantastic city view from the top. The caves have Jain heritage and rich history, making them a must-visit for history lovers. Entry tickets are affordable, and the area is clean and well-maintained. Monkeys roam around, so be careful with food. A great spot for photography and sightseeing!

placeMetadata.name: Odisha State Museum

sources.snippet: For those interested in history, the Odisha State Museum offers a fascinating glimpse into the regionâ€™s rich heritage. The museum houses a collection of artifacts, sculptures, and paintings that showcase Odishaâ€™s art and culture. Wandering through the exhibits can spark interesting conversations between couples, allowing you to learn more about each other while discovering the history of the region.

sources.snippet: Being a famous museum in the town Bhubaneswar, Odisha State Museum is highly visited by couples as it offers a different experience. The museum is categorized into 11 sections. The museum houses a huge collection of Jain and Buddhist sculptures, copper plates, coins, manuscripts, medieval and ancient tools and weapons, geological objects, paintings and much more.

Located in the education centre of BJB Nagar, the museum initially displayed a modest collection that included ancient coins, excavated sculptures etc. But over a period of time, it evolved and now houses a vast range of rare artefacts, archaeological specimens, preserved art collections and age-old manuscripts.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Odisha State Museum, established in 1932, originated from a collection of archaeological treasures by historians. Initially focused on archaeology, it now houses over 55,000 exhibits spanning various sections including archaeology, natural history, art and craft. The museum showcases sculptures, terracotta, numismatics, copper plates and fine arts. Visitors can explore musical instruments, rare palm leaf manuscripts, coins and Orissan tribal artifacts among other historical relics.

reviews.reviewText: My friend and I went to the Odisha State Museum, and we both enjoyed a lot there. It is located in the Kalpana Chowk infront of Utkal Kanika Galleria. There are numismatics, epigraphy, manuscripts, armoury, library, arts and crafts, mining and geology, natural history and anthropology, also there is The Kalinga Art Gallery, where you can look at the masterpieces of the artists all over the Odisha. The Odisha State Museum holds a lot of collections including The Kalinga Art Gallery over a two storey building in Kalpana Chowk, Bhubaneswar. I got to learn a lot about the rich culture of our Odisha. The ticket prices for each adult and child below 10 years are â‚¹20 and â‚¹10 respectively. Also you have to pay â‚¹10 extra for photography. Everyone must visit this place once in their life time including school children, because they ll get to know many more new things and rich heritage and culture about our state Odisha.

I went to the Odisha State Museum last month, and it was pretty cool.
I loved checking out all the art, artifacts, and cultural stuff there.
You could easily spend a couple of hours, or even more, just looking at all the art that shows off Indian and Odisha's culture.
Plus, the museum is clean and well-kept.
The ticket price is totally worth it. I'd definitely recommend it for school trips and tourists in Odisha.

ðŸ“State Museum, Bhubaneswar, Odisha

At a distance of 2 km from Bhubaneswar Railway Station, Odisha State Museum is a popular museum in Bhubaneswar. Renowned for its huge collection of manuscripts on palm leaves, this is one of the famous places to visit in Bhubaneswar.

Odisha State Museum was established in 1932 by Prof. N. C Banerjee & Prof. Ghanshyam Das. The museum started with a small display of archaeological treasures from several places. The small museum was then housed within the premises of the College. In 1938, by a suitable order, the Government of Odisha transformed this nucleus into the Provincial museum of Odisha. Today, it houses has an extensive collection of arts and artifacts. It is now maintained by the state government in collaboration with the Archaeological Department of India.

The museum is divided into eleven sections such as Archaeology, Epigraphy, Numismatics, Armoury, Mining & Geology, Natural History, Art & Craft, Contemporary Art, Patta Painting, Anthropology and Palm leaf Manuscripts. The four storey Odisha State Museum houses rich and invaluable collection of Buddhist and Jain sculptures, archeological findings, coins, copper plates, stone inscriptions from ancient and medieval Kalinga, armors, bronze age tools, ancient and medieval tools and weapons, enormous traditional dresses, stuffed animals, natural history, geological objects, paintings, anthropological specimens, traditional folk and musical instruments etc.

The palm leaf gallery is the most attractive one with a vast collection of rare Palm leaf Manuscripts including the 12th century manuscript of devotional poem Gita Govinda. It also has an impressive armour and weapon collection including the personal gun of Late Utkal Gaurava Madhusudan Das, a famous Oriya social reformer.

They have an impressive collection of artifacts from various timelines and dynasties. It's definitely worth the visit. I recommend going in the first half of the day so you have enough time to explore all the galleries at a relaxed pace.

Nandankanan Zoological Park, nestled 10â€¯km from Bhubaneswar, spans a lush 437â€¯hectares combining zoo, botanical garden, and wildlife sanctuary. Home to 157 species and over 3,500 animals including rare white tigers, gharials, and pangolins itâ€™s Indiaâ€™s first WAZA-accredited zoo.

Entry is â‚¹50 for adults, â‚¹10 for children, and â‚¹100 for foreigners. Safaris (lion, white tiger, bear, herbivore) cost â‚¹30/â‚¹15, while paddle-boat rides range from â‚¹50 to â‚¹150. A toy train and battery vehicles are also available, though small boat and safari queues occur during peak times. We paid 1500 for 3 people all with guide. It's take 3 -3.5 hrs entire park. Later depends upon you how much you spend.

Visit early morning (7:30â€¯AM) or late afternoon for optimal wildlife viewing; winters (Octâ€“Mar) are best.
The park is well-maintained, clean, and family-friendly, with a botanical garden, aquarium, library, and picnic spots.
However, avoid hiring overpriced guides many reviews advise self-guided exploration or using the battery vehicle to comfortably cover the large grounds. Overall, Nandankanan offers an enriching, educational, and enjoyable experience for wildlife lovers.

I had a fantastic time visiting Nandankanan Zoological Park! The entry ticket is very reasonably priced at just â‚¹50 per person, and it's absolutely worth every rupee for the experience you get. The zoo is home to a diverse range of animals and birds. I saw majestic white tigers, lions, leopards, elephants, rhinoceroses, giraffes, zebras, crocodiles, and hippopotamuses. For bird lovers, there's an impressive aviary with species like peacocks, parrots, hornbills, emus, ostriches, and many more colorful and exotic birds.

The zoo is clean, well-maintained, and the animals appear to be well cared for. There's ample space, shaded areas to rest, and food stalls for snacks and refreshments. Also, the adjoining botanical garden and lake add to the scenic beauty of the place.

Highly recommended for a day out with friends or family, especially if you're a nature or wildlife enthusiast. Can't wait to visit again!

placeMetadata.name: Dhauli Shanti Stupa

sources.snippet: Dhauli Shanti Stupa in Odisha stands as a symbol of peace and tranquility, perched atop Dhauli Hills overlooking the Daya River. This majestic white stupa, built in the early 1970s, commemorates the historic Kalinga War and Emperor Ashoka's transformative journey from conquest to Buddhism, promoting a message of non-violence and harmony.

The Dhauli Shanti Stupa, located near Bhubaneswar in Odisha, holds great historical and spiritual significance. It is believed to be the site of the Kalinga War (261 BCE), where Emperor Ashoka witnessed massive bloodshed that changed his heart. Deeply moved, Ashoka renounced violence and embraced Buddhism, spreading messages of peace and compassion. The Japanese Buddhist Sangha later built the white Peace Pagoda (Shanti Stupa) here in 1972, symbolizing harmony and non-violence. Surrounded by ancient rock edicts of Ashoka and serene landscapes, Dhauli Shanti Stupa stands as a reminder of transformation, peace, and the universal message of brotherhood.

Experience: Not much to explore, but it is a peaceful and pleasant place to visit. The four statues of Buddha each depict a story. I am not sure if private vehicles are allowed near the temple, as we traveled there on a small government bus.

The four Buddha statues at Dhauli Shanti Stupa (Peace Pagoda), Odisha represent the four significant stages of Lord Buddhaâ€™s life. Each statue is placed facing one direction of the stupa, symbolizing peace and compassion:

Birth of Buddha (Lumbini) â€“ Depicts the moment of Siddhartha Gautamaâ€™s birth.

Enlightenment (Bodh Gaya) â€“ Represents Buddha attaining enlightenment under the Bodhi tree.

First Sermon (Sarnath) â€“ Symbolizes the "Dharmachakra Pravartan" (Turning of the Wheel of Dharma) when he first taught the path.

Mahaparinirvana (Kushinagar) â€“ Depicts Buddhaâ€™s final departure from the world, symbolizing eternal peace.

These statues together narrate Buddhaâ€™s journey and convey the message of non-violence, compassion, and universal peace.

A peaceful and spiritual place with stunning views and historical significance. The white stupa, surrounded by greenery, offers a calm and serene atmosphere. From the top, you can enjoy a panoramic view of the surrounding area, including parts of the city and the Daya River. There's no entry fee, and a good parking space is available nearby. A must-visit spot near Puri for those interested in history, Buddhism, or just a quiet break from the city.

It's located in a hilly area. Peaceful and calm. The statue area is marbled. Enough space for sitting around,relaxing. Ample car parking space. Small shops with souvenirs available. Lift for senior citizens was not working. People with knee problems can avoid climbing up.

Dhauli Shanti Stupa â€“ A Peaceful Gem Just Outside Bhubaneswar

Tucked atop a quiet hill on the outskirts of Bhubaneswar, the Dhauli Shanti Stupa is a little slice of serenity. The moment you step up to it, thereâ€™s a real sense of calm in the air - something about the white domed structure against the sky just puts your heart at ease.

The stupa itself is a beauty - gracefully built, with stunning carvings and elegant depictions of Lord Buddha in various postures. You donâ€™t have to be deeply spiritual to feel the stillness of the place. Itâ€™s peaceful in a way that makes you want to just sit, take a breath, and let the world slow down a bit.

From the top, you get a sweeping view of the Daya River flowing gently through the landscape - absolutely cracking at sunset, when the whole place is bathed in gold. Mind you, in the heat of the afternoon, it can get a bit much, especially since shoes have to come off - so aim for an evening visit if you can.

Itâ€™s free to enter, easy to reach by car, and honestly, itâ€™s well worth the short drive out from the city. Whether youâ€™re into history, architecture, or just fancy a peaceful moment with a view, Dhauliâ€™s a spot thatâ€™ll stay with you.

Located in the heart of Bhubaneswar, Biju Patnaik Park is a serene and well-maintained urban oasis that caters equally to children, adults, and fitness enthusiasts. Spread over a vast area, the park is a tribute to the legendary leader Biju Patnaik and reflects the city's commitment to green and inclusive public spaces.

Biju Patnaik Park, located in the heart of Bhubaneswar, is a sprawling 23-acre urban oasis dedicated to the memory of the former Chief Minister of Odisha, Biju Patnaik. Originally known as Forest Park, it was renamed in his honor and a statue of him stands in the middle of the park.
This popular recreational space offers a refreshing escape with its expansive green spaces, manicured gardens, vibrant rosaries, and picturesque rockeries. Fitness enthusiasts can enjoy the jogging tracks (clay, tiled, and concrete) and an open-air gym. There's also a dedicated children's play area with various equipment.
Key attractions include three serene water bodies, a musical fountain, and activity centers. The park is a favorite among locals for morning walks, yoga sessions, and evening relaxation. It's a family-friendly destination with ample space for picnics and leisure.
Open from 4:00 AM to 12:00 PM and again from 3:00 PM to 9:00 PM, with no entry fee, Biju Patnaik Park is a significant green lung in the city, offering a peaceful retreat for all.

A Magnificent Journey into Kalinga's Heart, with a Word of Caution
Standing as the magnificent soul of Bhubaneswar, the "Temple City of India," the Lingaraj Temple is an architectural marvel and a spiritual behemoth. My recent visit was a journey back in time, a sensory experience filled with awe, devotion, and a slight touch of modern-day reality.
A Glimpse into History
Before you even step inside, the temple's history looms as large as its towering spire. Built in the 11th century by King Jajati Keshari of the Somavamsi dynasty, Lingaraj Temple is the quintessential example of Kalinga architecture in its full maturity. It is dedicated to Lord Shiva as Harihara â€“ a unique form that represents the syncretism of Shaivism (Shiva) and Vaishnavism (Vishnu). The central deity is a Swayambhu (self-manifested) lingam, which is considered incredibly sacred. The sprawling complex, with its 50-odd smaller shrines, is a testament to centuries of faith and masterful craftsmanship.
The Awe-Inspiring Experience
The moment you pass through the main gate, the sheer scale of the main sanctum's tower (Vimana), soaring to a height of 180 feet, is breathtaking. The intricate carvings that adorn every inch of the sandstone structure are a sight to behold. Deities, celestial beings, mythical creatures, and floral patterns tell a thousand stories etched in stone. The atmosphere inside is thick with spirituality; the air is filled with the fragrance of incense, ghee lamps, and flowers, accompanied by the continuous murmur of chants and ringing bells. The feeling of being in a living, breathing place of worship that has been active for a thousand years is truly profound.
The Dissonance: Where Commerce Meets Piety
However, this sublime spiritual experience was unfortunately marred by a very worldly issue. As I neared the inner sanctum (Garbhagriha) to get a glimpse of the deity, the commercial aspect of the temple became glaringly apparent. A number of pujaris (priests) were quite insistent, bordering on aggressive, in directing devotees towards special pujas.
My personal experience was a bit disheartening. I was approached and told that for a proper blessing and prasad, a special puja was necessary. The price quoted was a staggering â‚¹2000. When I politely declined, expressing my desire for just a simple darshan, the attitude soured. This transactional nature of worship felt deeply out of place within such a sacred space. It creates an uncomfortable environment, making one feel that blessings are conditional on payment, which goes against the very grain of spiritual seeking. For a pilgrim who comes with pure devotion, this can be a very jarring and disappointing experience.
Final Verdict
The Lingaraj Temple is, without a doubt, an unmissable destination. Its architectural grandeur and historical significance are unparalleled. It is a masterpiece that every history, art, and architecture enthusiast must see.
However, visitors should be prepared for the commercial pressures within. My advice would be to be firm yet polite. You are not obligated to pay for any special puja to receive blessings. Go for the divine art, the palpable history, and the spiritual aura. But be prepared for the very human commerce that operates within its sacred walls. It is a magnificent monument, but one where you must navigate the material to experience the spiritual.
Key Tips for Visitors:
* No Cameras or Phones: They are strictly prohibited inside. You can deposit them at a locker outside for a small fee.
* Dress Code: Modest attire is required. Cover your shoulders and knees.
* Entry: Please note that only Hindus are permitted to enter the temple premises. Others can get a decent view from a viewing platform built nearby.

The Lingaraja temple is the largest temple in Bhubaneswar.Â Â (James Fergusson 1808â€“86), a noted critic and historian rated the temple as "one of the finest examples of purely Hindu temple temple in India".It is enshrined within a spacious compound wall of Laterite ofÂ Â measuring 520Â ft (160Â m) by 465Â ft (142Â m). The wall is 7.5Â ft (2.3Â m) thick and surmounted by a plain slant coping. Alongside the inner face of the boundary wall, there is a terrace to protect the compound wall against outside aggression. The tower is 45.11Â m (148.0Â ft) high and the complex has 150 smaller shrines in its spacious courtyard. Each inch of the 55Â m (180Â ft) tall tower is sculpted. The door in the gate of the entrance porch is made of sandalwood.
The temple has a vast courtyard mired with hundreds of small shrines.

Other significant areas are

The Bhogamandapa (Hall of offering)

Tickets Required plus need to deposit Cell Phone & allied as no photocopy allowed.

Lingaraj Temple in Bhubaneswar is a famous and beautiful temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is very old and has amazing stone carvings. The place feels peaceful and holy. Itâ€™s a must-visit for history and culture lovers.

The Lingaraja Temple in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, is a highly revered Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. Will definitely appreciate its impressive architectural grandeur and deep spiritual significance.

It has magnificent Kalinga-style architecture with its towering spire, intricate carvings, and numerous shrines within the complex. The carvings depict scenes from Hindu mythology and reflect the artistry of the Kalinga dynasty. Me and my family felt a powerful and positive spiritual energy within the temple complex, especially when touching the sacred Shivling. The temple offers a serene and peaceful environment for devotees seeking blessings and inner tranquility.

The temple dates back to the 11th century and represents Odisha's rich heritage and architectural prowess. It's considered a significant landmark symbolizing the coexistence of Shaivism and Vaishnavism. The temple's large Shivalinga, the Maha Bhog Kitchen where food is cooked traditionally, and the Bindusagar tank (believed to have healing waters).

During festivals and auspicious days, the temple can get very crowded, impacting the ease of darshan (viewing the deity). One problem is cleanliness within the main temple and the area where offerings are consumed. Photography, mobile phones, bags, shoes, and leather items are strictly prohibited inside the temple premises. A dedicated area is provided outside for depositing these items.

Overall, a visit to this temple is a must for anyone seeking a glimpse into the rich cultural heritage.

Nestled in Nayapalli, Bhubaneswar, Ekamra Kananâ€”also known as the RPRC Botanical Gardenâ€”is a refreshing escape into natureâ€™s embrace. Spanning an impressive 487â€“500 acres, this verdant haven is managed by the Regional Plant Resource Centre and has been a city landmark since its founding in 1985  ï¿¼.

As you wander through its diverse landscapes, you encounter several distinct zones. The highlight is the Cactus Garden, covering around 100 acres, featuring over 1,000 succulent and cactus varieties in a striking pyramid-style glasshouse  ï¿¼. Nearby, themed flower gardensâ€”scented flowers, hibiscus, and a vast rose gardenâ€”showcase hundreds of plant species, enhancing both your senses and Instagram feed  ï¿¼.

A serene 40-acre artificial lake lies at the heart of the garden. Visitors can enjoy & simply admire the migratory birdlife, especially during winter  ï¿¼. A nearby birdwatching tower offers panoramic views of the lake and surrounding greenery  ï¿¼.

Families love the childrenâ€™s play zone with swings, slides, and a musical fountainâ€”sure to delight younger guests  ï¿¼. Natural walking trails, built for morning and evening fitness routines, thread through woodland scenery, connecting visitors with the adjacent Chandaka forest  ï¿¼.

Amenities bolster the visitor experience: thoughtful walking trails (3â€¯km), well-kept benches, restrooms, drinking water stations, and on-site stalls offering local handicrafts and light refreshments  ï¿¼. The parkâ€™s popularity surges during the annual January flower show, a vibrant showcase of horticultural skills .

reviews.reviewText:
Visiting the Regional Museum of Natural History, Bhubaneswar was a great experience! The museum is well-organized and has amazing displays about nature, wildlife, and tribal life. One of the best parts is the life-size animal models, which make you feel like you're in a real jungle.

The museum has sections on different animals, birds, marine life, and even fossils. Seeing dinosaur fossils up close was really exciting! The tribal section teaches about how local communities live in harmony with nature. Everything is presented in a simple and interesting way, so both kids and adults can enjoy it.

What I loved the most was how interactive and educational the museum is. There are plenty of things to learn, and itâ€™s a great place for school trips and families. Plus, the best partâ€”itâ€™s completely free! The museum is well-maintained, and the staff is friendly.

If you are in Bhubaneswar and love nature or wildlife, this place is a must-visit. Itâ€™s a peaceful and informative place where you can spend a couple of hours exploring and learning. Highly recommended for nature lovers, students, and anyone curious about the world around us!

I really enjoyed my visit to the Regional Museum of Natural History. The exhibits are not only informative but also beautifully arranged. I was especially impressed by the fossil section and the life-size animal models â€” they truly bring nature to life. It's a peaceful and inspiring place, perfect for a weekend visit with family or friends. Highly recommended.
Absolute delight to tour this museum. There are so many things for a curious mind in this museum. Definitely a must visit place if you are planning a vacation in Bhubaneswar

Wonderful Summer Camp Experience at RMNH, Bhubaneswar

The recent 7-day Summer Camp organized by RMNH, Bhubaneswar was an exceptional and enriching experience for children across Odisha. Students from various schools were invited to take part in this well-structured and thoughtfully curated program.

From day one, the camp was filled with excitement and learning. The organizers did a fantastic job of balancing educational activities with creative and recreational ones. Children engaged in sessions on wildlife and environmental awareness, participated in art, dance, and music, and even went on two educational picnics that brought learning to life in a fun and interactive way.

The RMNH team showed incredible dedication, ensuring that every child felt cared for, engaged, and inspired. The camp concluded on June 5, aligning beautifully with World Environment Day, with a special valedictory program, where students were awarded certificates recognizing their active involvement and achievements during the summer program week.

A big thank you to the entire team at RMNH, Bhubaneswar for creating such a memorable and impactful experience. I truly hope my kids get the opportunity to be a part of this incredible camp again next year!!

This museum is located in the middle of the city, (Bhubaneswar) next to the Pathani Samanta Planetarium (acharya bihar). There is a beautiful garden at the entrance of the museum where there are many kinds of flowers. No tickets are charged here, you can watch it for free.
In the museum, the bodies of many animals, birds and reptiles are kept in a safe condition after their death. There are skeletons of a giant whale, a rhino and a tusked elephant on display. Various types of butterflies and snakes have also been kept. You can also increase your knowledge by seeing many types of stones, minerals and stones.

Odisha Regional Museum, located near Pathani Samanta Planetarium, is a treasure of history, nature, and culture. It features a botanical garden designed for the visually impaired, a vivarium, and interactive activities that make it fun for kids too. One of the highlights is the animal skeleton section and preserved reptiles like cobras, which draw curiosity and wonder. Regional Museum Bhubaneswar, just next to Pathani Samanta Planetarium, is a beautiful place to have an idea about biodiversity. Free to visit, no ticket is  needed.

The Regional Museum of Natural History in Bhubaneswar is an engaging and educational destination that offers a fascinating insight into the natural world. Established in 2004, the museum serves as an excellent platform for learning about the regionâ€™s rich biodiversity, geology, and cultural heritage. Spread across multiple galleries, the exhibits showcase a variety of specimens, including preserved plants, fossils, and taxidermy animals, providing visitors with a deeper understanding of wildlife and ecosystems.

One of the museumâ€™s highlights is the life-sized diorama of animals in their natural habitats, which captivates both children and adults alike. The skeletons of marine creatures and fossils of prehistoric animals draw special attention, offering a glimpse into the ancient past. Additionally, there are sections dedicated to marine life and forests of Odisha, emphasizing conservation and environmental awareness.

The museum is well-maintained, with interactive displays and informative panels that make learning enjoyable. Its serene surroundings, complemented by a beautifully landscaped garden, provide a peaceful environment for visitors. Admission is free, making it accessible to everyone, including school groups and families.

Whether you're a nature enthusiast, a student, or a curious traveler, the Regional Museum of Natural History is a must-visit attraction in Bhubaneswar for an enriching and memorable experience.

Indian artÂ consists of a variety of art forms, includingÂ painting,Â sculpture,Â pottery, andÂ textile artsÂ such asÂ woven silk. Geographically, it spans the entireÂ Indian subcontinent, including what is nowÂ India,Â Pakistan,Â Bangladesh,Â Sri Lanka,Â Nepal,Â BhutanÂ and easternÂ Afghanistan. A strong sense of design is characteristic of Indian art and can be observed in its modern and traditional forms.
The origin of Indian art can be traced toÂ pre-historicÂ settlements in the 3rd millennium BC. On its way to modern times, Indian art has had cultural influences, as well as religious influences such asÂ Hinduism,Â Buddhism,Â Jainism,Â SikhismÂ andÂ Islam. In spite of this complex mixture of religious traditions, generally, the prevailing artistic style at any time and place has been shared by the major religious groups.
In historic art, sculpture in stone and metal, mainly religious, has survived the Indian climate better than other media and provides most of the best remains. Many of the most important ancient finds that are not in carved stone come from the surrounding, drier regions rather than India itself.Â Indian funeralÂ and philosophic traditions excludeÂ grave goods, which is the main source of ancient art in other cultures.
Indian artist styles historically followedÂ Indian religionsÂ out of the subcontinent, having an especially large influence inÂ Tibet,Â South East AsiaÂ andÂ China. Indian art has itself received influences at times, especially fromÂ Central AsiaÂ andÂ Iran, and Europe.

The Netaji Subash Chandra Bose Park in Bhubaneswar, Telegraph pictures
Bhubaneswar, Dec. 19: Spread over 17 acres of prime land, Netaji Subash Chandra Bose Park in Gandamunda had everything that could have made it the ultimate destination for the cityâ€™s young and old looking for a place to recreate and do some physical exercises.

In reality, however, the park, which seems to have gone to seed over the years with unkempt lawns, a badly eroded jogging track and generally unclean surroundings, hardly witnesses any footfall. The poor lighting and the absence of boundary wall on the one side of the park have only made matters worse.

Established in 1998, the park once had grand plans for installing a statue of Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose with a fountain around it. Now the entire area is covered with wild bushes with venomous snakes hiding here and there.

Md Sarfaz Alam, an electrical contractor who lives in the area, said that such is the fear of snakes that people donâ€™t dare to enter the park during summer and the rainy season. The gates of the park remain closed almost always and the only security man guarding the place has not received his salary for the past two years. â€œThe park opens according to his whims,â€ Alam added. etc. provide added beauty to the park. Large benches are placed throughout theThe park is one of the famous visitor spots of the capital town of Bhubaneswar. The park is adorned in a lovely manner. The pathways, light systems, strolling tracks, sprinklers and so on. Offer added beauty to the park.As the Bhubaneswar Development Authority (BDA), which is tasked with the management and maintenance of the park, apparently seems to be not interested in performing its duties, the nearby slumdwellers let their cattle lose into the park through the open boundary.

Admitting that the park was suffering on account of indifference, the official said that some of the installations like fountains had stopped working as repairs did not take place on time.

Large benches are located for the duration of the park to permit human beings sit and revel in the environment of the park. The clean air of the vicinity mixed with the desirable greenery could make all and sundryâ€™s coronary heart wander and force him to stay lower back a touch longer inside the park. Every day loads of nearby people and travelers go to the park to have a chilled time. Children also love to be at this beautiful park. The parkâ€™s timing is 4.00 PM to 8.00 PM & 5.00 AM to 8.00 AM day by day.

For many of us in Bhubaneswar, Janta Maidan is more than just a green space; it's a landmark we've grown up with. As kids, we might have run around its open grounds, enjoying the simple pleasure of space in a developing city. Even now, it remains a popular spot for morning walks and evening strolls, offering a breath of fresh air away from the urban bustle.
The park is dedicated to Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose, a towering figure in India's independence movement, and it's a fitting tribute. The well-maintained pathways, the trees providing shade, and the benches scattered around offer a peaceful environment to reflect and perhaps remember his contributions. The gentle lighting in the evenings adds to its charm.
However, Janta Maidan's identity extends beyond just being a park. It's the city's go-to venue for large-scale events. I've attended numerous trade fairs, cultural melas (like the Toshali Mela), and exhibitions here over the years. During these events, the atmosphere transforms completely. The grounds come alive with vibrant stalls, bustling crowds, and the sounds of commerce and celebration. It's a place where you can find everything from traditional handicrafts and handlooms to the latest consumer goods. The annual India International Mega Trade Fair is a particularly big draw.
It's interesting how this space seamlessly transitions between a tranquil park for daily recreation and a dynamic hub for major city events. This versatility makes Janta Maidan a truly important and recognizable place in Bhubaneswar. While it might not have elaborate landscaping or amusement rides like some other parks, its open expanse and its role as a central event ground give it a unique character and a special place in the hearts of the locals. We see it not just as a park, but as a vital part of Bhubaneswar's social and cultural fabric.
Looks small from outside but beautifully maintained and has a long track to accommodate a good number of people.

reviews.reviewText: The Mukteswara Temple, located in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, is a 10th-century temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is considered a masterpiece of Kalinga-style architecture, often called the "Gem of Odisha architecture." The temple is renowned for its ornate torana (arched gateway), intricate carvings of celestial beings, and detailed sculptural work. The Shiva Lingam inside is a revered pilgrimage site. The temple also showcases early influences of Buddhist and Jain architecture. Situated in the Old Town near major temples like Lingaraj, it is easily accessible by taxis, auto-rickshaws, and local buses, making it a must-visit heritage site.

The Mukteswar Temple in Bhubaneswar is a stunning example of early Kalinga architecture and is often regarded as the â€œGem of Odisha architecture.â€ Built in the 10th century, this small yet intricately designed temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is renowned for its beautifully carved arched gateway (torana), exquisite sculptures, and detailed motifs depicting scenes from mythology and everyday life. The templeâ€™s elegant design, harmonious proportions, and fine craftsmanship make it a must-visit for lovers of art, history, and architecture. Surrounded by a peaceful ambiance, it offers a serene spiritual experience, right in the heart of the city.

Located in the heart of Bhubaneswar, the Mukteshwar Temple is one of the finest examples of ancient Odisha-style (Kalinga) temple architecture. Dating back to the 10th century, this small yet artistically rich temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva (Mukteshwar Mahadev).

Though not very large, every inch of the temple is beautifully carved â€” from intricate floral patterns to scenes from mythology. The iconic arched torana (gateway) at the entrance is unique and unmatched in design among Indian temples, giving it the nickname â€œGem of Odisha architecture.â€

The temple is peaceful and less crowded, making it ideal for quiet exploration, photography, or spiritual reflection. Itâ€™s also part of the famous â€œEkamra Kshetraâ€ â€” the old temple city area, and is located near other historical temples like Rajarani and Lingaraj.

Mukteshwar Temple, built in the 10th century by the Somavamshi dynasty, is a stunning gem of Kalinga architecture. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, its most striking feature is the intricately carved torana (arched gateway), flanked by glassy lattice windows and playful monkey and Panchatantra motifs.

The compact shrine includes a pyramidal jagamohana adorned with intricate sculptures of ascetics and deities . Located in a serene garden complex, it exudes spiritual calm and showcases Odishaâ€™s temple evolution .

Open daily from ~6:30â€¯AMâ€“7:30â€¯PM with free entry, this â€œgem of Odisha architectureâ€ is ideal for heritage enthusiasts and anyone seeking tranquility amid historic artistry

The Brahmeswar Temple in Bhubaneswar is a masterpiece of Kalinga architecture, standing as a testament to Odishaâ€™s rich heritage. Built in 1058 CE by Kolavati Devi, the mother of Somavamsi king Udyotakesari, this temple marks an important transition in temple design, showcasing intricate craftsmanship and artistic excellence.

Carved out of sandstone, the temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and features breathtaking sculptures of celestial dancers, musicians, and mythological figures. The introduction of iron beams in construction and the first use of surasundaris (heavenly maidens) on temple walls make it a significant milestone in temple architecture.

Surrounded by smaller shrines, Brahmeswar Templeâ€™s sanctum enshrines a powerful Shiva Lingam, drawing devotees and history lovers alike. The templeâ€™s rekha deul (curvilinear spire) and the exquisite nagara-style carvings tell stories of devotion, art, and cultural grandeur. Even after nearly a thousand years, it remains a serene and spiritual landmark in Bhubaneswar, the City of Temples.

The Brahmeshwar Temple, located in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, is a 9th-century temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. Built in Kalinga-style architecture, it features an elaborate rekha deula (tower) and intricate carvings of divine figures, musicians, and dancers. The temple marks the transition to more elaborate Odishan temple designs, influencing later structures like Lingaraj Temple. The presence of tantric symbols suggests tantric worship was practiced here. Surrounded by smaller shrines, it holds deep religious and historical significance. Situated about 10 km from the city center, it is easily accessible by taxis, auto-rickshaws, and local buses, making it a must-visit heritage site.

**Ekamra Haat, Bhubaneswar** is a vibrant cultural and craft hub that showcases Odisha's rich heritage. Located in the heart of the city, it serves as a one-stop destination for authentic handicrafts, handlooms, and regional delicacies.

### **Key Highlights**:
1. **Art and Craft**:
- The haat features an array of stalls offering traditional Odisha handicrafts such as Pattachitra paintings, stone carvings, terracotta, appliquÃ© work, and silver filigree.
- Visitors can also explore handloom products like Sambalpuri sarees, Ikat fabrics, and tribal jewelry.

2. **Food Court**:
- The food court serves an assortment of Odia delicacies like Pakhala Bhata, Dalma, Chhena Poda, and more, giving visitors a taste of authentic regional cuisine.

3. **Cultural Programs**:
- Regular cultural performances, including Odissi dance and folk music, add a lively ambiance and celebrate Odisha's artistic heritage.

4. **Ambience**:
- The open-air setup, beautifully landscaped surroundings, and traditional architecture create a serene and welcoming environment.

5. **Affordability and Accessibility**:
- The products are reasonably priced, making it an excellent place for tourists and locals to purchase souvenirs.
- Its central location makes it easily accessible for everyone.

### **Visitor Experience**:
Ekamra Haat is highly rated for its cleanliness, friendly vendors, and authentic offerings. Itâ€™s a must-visit for anyone interested in Odishaâ€™s art, culture, and cuisine.

**Recommendation**: Perfect for families, tourists, and culture enthusiasts looking to explore and experience Odisha's vibrant heritage.

Five Stars for Ekamra Haat!
If you're in Bhubaneswar and want a real taste of Odisha (and beyond!), Ekamra Haat is an absolute gem. I loved just strolling around, it has such a lovely, relaxed vibe. The way they've designed the stalls like little village huts gives it so much character.
I spent ages Browse the handicrafts â€“ the Pattachitra paintings are simply stunning, and I picked up some beautiful handloom fabric. It's so cool to see the artisans actually demonstrating their skills right there. You feel like you're getting a genuine piece of art, directly from the person who made it.
And the food! Oh my goodness, the food stalls are a must-try. I indulged in some delicious local Odia snacks that I still think about.
It's a fantastic spot for souvenirs, or just to soak in some local culture. Highly recommend a visit, whether you're a tourist or a local looking for something unique. Definitely brings a smile to your face!

Akamra Haat in Bhubaneswar is a vibrant cultural and shopping hub that beautifully showcases Odisha's rich heritage. Located near Ekamra Kanan, this open-air marketplace is a treat for art enthusiasts, shopaholics, and food lovers alike. The haat is a perfect blend of tradition and modernity, offering a variety of handcrafted items, textiles, and souvenirs that reflect the skilled craftsmanship of local artisans. From intricate Pattachitra paintings to Sambalpuri sarees and terracotta artifacts, the collection is diverse and authentic.

The ambience of Akamra Haat is equally captivating, with its neatly designed stalls, open spaces, and a festive vibe. Regularly hosting cultural events, including dance and music performances, it adds an engaging experience for visitors, giving them a taste of Odishaâ€™s cultural essence. The food stalls serving local delicacies such as dahi bara aloo dum, chakuli pitha, and rasagola are an added delight.

One of the highlights is its affordability, making it an excellent destination for both tourists and locals. However, parking can be challenging during peak hours, and the area can get crowded during festivals. Overall, Akamra Haat is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to immerse themselves in Odishaâ€™s cultural and artistic richness.

The Botanical Garden in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, is a beautiful and serene place that offers visitors a chance to connect with nature and enjoy a peaceful retreat from the hustle and bustle of city life. Spread over 173 acres of land, the garden boasts a vast collection of plants, trees, and flowers worldwide.

The garden is home to several rare and endangered species of plants, making it a significant center for conservation efforts. Visitors can stroll through the garden's various sections, including the cactus house, medicinal plant section, and palm grove, among others.

One of the highlights is the Japanese garden, which features a beautiful pond, a bridge, and carefully curated plants that create a tranquil atmosphere. The park also has a musical fountain that adds charm and beauty.

The garden's well-manicured lawns and well-maintained pathways make it an ideal place for picnics and family outings. The park also has several benches and seating areas where visitors can relax and soak in the beauty of their surroundings.

The staff at the Botanical Garden is knowledgeable and friendly, providing valuable insights into the garden's various sections and plants. Overall, the Botanical Garden in Bhubaneswar is a must-visit for anyone interested in nature and its wonders. It offers an excellent opportunity to connect with nature while enjoying a day out with family and friends.

"A serene and beautifully maintained garden, perfect for nature lovers and families. The variety of themed gardens offer a diverse and educational experience. The Butterfly Park is a highlight, with many species fluttering around. Don't miss the Glass House and the extensive collection of bonsais and orchids. Ideal for a relaxing day out amidst nature."

Jugaad Junction:
A Culinary Gem in Bhubaneswar!
Nestled in the heart of Bhubaneswar, Jugaad Junction isn't just a restaurant; it's an experience! From the moment you step inside, you're greeted by a vibrant and quirky ambiance that perfectly blends modern aesthetics with a touch of rustic charm. The creative decor, often incorporating recycled materials (true to its name, "jugaad" meaning resourceful improvisation!), sparks conversation and adds a unique character to the space.
But the real star of the show is undoubtedly the food. As a pure vegetarian restaurant, Jugaad Junction offers a delightful array of dishes that cater to all taste buds. Whether you're craving North Indian classics, satisfying snacks, or innovative fusion creations, their extensive menu has something to tantalize your palate.
Here are some highlights that make Jugaad Junction stand out:
* Delicious and High-Quality Food: Every dish is prepared with fresh, quality ingredients, ensuring a burst of flavor in every bite. Their commitment to taste is evident in their popular items like the Chole Bhature, Paneer Paratha, and the flavorful Matar Paneer Khichdi.
* Affordable Prices: You can enjoy a satisfying and delicious meal without breaking the bank. This makes it a go-to spot for students, families, and anyone looking for value for money.
* Unique Ambiance: The interiors are truly enchanting, with creative use of materials that give the place a distinctive and eye-catching appeal. It's a great backdrop for casual hangouts and memorable meals.
* Friendly and Efficient Service: The staff are generally known for their warm and cooperative behavior, adding to the overall positive dining experience.
* Diverse Menu: From hearty Thalis and fulfilling Parathas to quick and tasty snacks like Papdi Chat and Samosa Chat, there's a wide variety to choose from. Don't miss their refreshing beverages like the Namkeen Chach and Malai Lassi.
* Convenient Locations: With multiple outlets across Bhubaneswar, including Patia, Kalinga Nagar, and Laxmisagar, Jugaad Junction is easily accessible from various parts of the city.
It's a place where you can enjoy tasty vegetarian food in a lively and welcoming atmosphere.
Whether you're a local or a visitor in Bhubaneswar, a meal at Jugaad Junction is highly recommended for a flavorful and memorable experience!

Utkal University is the first and largest university in Odisha. It was established in 1943 and is located in Vani Vihar, Bhubaneswar. The university offers courses in various subjects, including Arts, Science, Commerce, Law, Management, and Social Sciences.

The academic standards of the university are good, and the faculty members are experienced. Research and publications have improved significantly over the years. The university has a large library, which is helpful for students. There are also many clubs, cultural programs, and sports activities that play an important role in student life.

Although the university has decent infrastructure, some areas lack modern facilities. In some departments, the number of faculty members is low, which can sometimes create difficulties in academics. However, in terms of education quality, Utkal University is a good option for students.

Overall, it is one of the best universities in Odisha, offering good educational opportunities.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally weâ€™re always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Bhubaneswar, the capital city of Odisha, is a treasure trove of romance, where ancient temples and lush parks create the perfect backdrop for love. Imagine strolling hand-in-hand with your partner through the serene pathways of Ekamra Kanan or sharing a quiet moment at the stunning Dhauli Shanti Stupa, where the whispers of history blend seamlessly with the gentle breeze. This city, rich in culture and heritage, offers a unique blend of experiences that cater to couples seeking both adventure and tranquility.

As you explore Bhubaneswar, you'll discover charming spots like the intricately carved Ram Mandir and the peaceful Biju Patnaik Park, where you can enjoy a leisurely picnic amidst nature. Whether you're indulging in a delightful meal at Malva Restaurant or wandering through the Odisha State Museum, the city invites you to create unforgettable memories together. So pack your bags and get ready to uncover the romantic gems of Bhubaneswar, where every corner holds the promise of a beautiful experience.

placeMetadata.name: Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves

sources.snippet: At a distance of 9 km from Bhubaneswar Railway Station, Udayagiri & Khandagiri are two ancient Jain rock-cut caves located in the vicinity of Bhubaneswar. Called as twin hills caves, these caves are one of the most popular places to visit in Bhubaneswar and also one of the best places of heritage in Odisha. Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves have derived their names, owing to their location on two hills, Udayagiri and Khandagiri.
sources.shortName: 23 Best Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: The part natural and part artificial caves were built around the 1st century BC and the subsequent years by the Chedi Dynasty. The caves contain several Jain temples and monasteries said to have been built by King Kharavela and contains a total of 33 caves. Udayagiri and Khandgiri Caves are again exemplary of some fine stone carving by the Kalinga artisans.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Attractions In Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: Perhaps you recognise the tourist attraction in Bhubaneswar as Cuttack caves. These popular human-made caves are a key attraction that tourists simply cannot miss. With carved inscriptions and figures of the plenty of tribal communities who once lived in Bhubaneswar, there is a lot of historical and cultural significance that you can witness here.
sources.shortName: 10 Tourist Places in Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: An ideal location for a young couple who loves history and nature to get some snaps before getting married is at Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves. These ancient caves carved out of natural rocks are famous for their sculptures, architecture and views. The caves provide a unique setting for pre-wedding photos, adding a sense of mystery and grandeur.
sources.shortName: Best 7 Pre-Wedding Photoshoot Places in Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: Situated a few miles away from Bhubaneswar, the Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are rock cut caves believed to have been carved out by Jain monks. The caves sit adjacent to each other and have inscriptions written all over its walls. Within the two caves, there are many small caves that have important stone carvings, footprints, and sculptures.
sources.shortName: The 15 Most Iconic Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: Located 7 kilometers away from Bhubaneswar, the Khandagiri Caves are ancient artificial structures from the 2nd century BC. These rock-cut caves were built by King Kharavela of the Meghavahana dynasty. They are decorated with intricate mythological carvings and regal inscriptions and are popularly known as Cuttack Caves.
sources.shortName: 23 Best Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: The name of the two caves, comes mainly from their location on the hills with the respective names. Located across a road, the two caves literally stand facing each other. They are believed to have been carved out as residential accommodation for Jain monks during the reign of King Kharavela.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar, Tourist Places & Attractions

sources.snippet: The Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are archaeologically, historically, and religiously significant caves which are one of the eminent tourist sites in the city of Odisha. The majority of these caves are thought to have been used by Jain monks as living places during King Kharavela's rule.
sources.shortName: Tourist Places & Top Things to Do in 2024

sources.snippet: Credits: Phadke09, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons. One of the twin caves of Bhubaneswar is the Udayagiri Caves. With 18 existing caves, it stands tall with historically significant ancient sculptures and reliefs.
sources.shortName: 47 Best Tourist Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar 2024

sources.snippet: Apart from being historical wonders, these caves are scenic and tranquil. The beauty lies in the architecture of these rock-cut shelters, which brings it to this list. The detailing and the textures can make any photography enthusiast fall for the place.
sources.shortName: Top 7 Locations In Bhubaneswar For Your Next Photoshoot

sources.snippet: These caves are more than just caves, in other words, a grand treat to your eyes. They are ancient caves cut out from rocks, inspired by Jainism style of architecture. It closely represents the heritage of Odisha.
sources.shortName: 7 Best Places to visit in Bhubaneswar

placeMetadata.description: Elaborately carved cave dwellings dating to the 1st c. BCE, topped by an 18th-c. CE Jain temple.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled just 6 kilometers from the vibrant city of Bhubaneshwar, the Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are a treasure trove of ancient history, dating back to the 1st century BCE. These intricately carved cave dwellings served as homes for Jain ascetics and offer a unique glimpse into their simple yet profound lifestyle.
placeMetadata.address: 7Q7M+2V7, Khandagiri, Bhubaneswar, Odisha 751030, India

reviews.reviewText: Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are really amazing to visit. These ancient caves are beautifully carved and have a lot of history connected to Jain monks. The stone carvings are worth seeing, and some caves also give you a glimpse of meditation cells used in old times. The view from the top is also nice and peaceful. Best time to visit is in the evening or early morning when itâ€™s not too hot.

Situated on the outskirts of a bustling city in Odisha, this ancient site is a remarkable blend of history, spirituality, and nature. Carved into solid rock, the twin hill structures hold centuries-old caves that once served as dwellings and meditation chambers for monks. These rock-cut marvels are not just architectural wonders but also sacred spaces that echo the deep roots of Jainism and its teachings in the region.

The caves are adorned with intricate carvings, inscriptions, and symbolic motifs that reflect the simplicity and discipline of monastic life. Each chamber tells a silent tale of devotion, enlightenment, and the human quest for inner peace. The cool interiors, despite the surrounding heat, offer a calming and reflective environment, inviting visitors to pause and connect with a timeless past.

The surrounding landscape adds to the charm â€” lush greenery, chirping birds, and panoramic views of the city from the hilltops create a perfect blend of history and natural beauty. Climbing the stone steps to explore each cave is like walking through the pages of a living history book. The serenity of the place makes it a favorite for spiritual seekers, historians, and nature lovers alike.

What truly sets this site apart is its silent endurance through the ages. It continues to inspire with its blend of art, faith, and resilience. Whether it's a quiet sunrise visit or a thoughtful exploration of the caves, the experience leaves one with a deep appreciation for Odishaâ€™s ancient legacy and the peaceful strength of its spiritual traditions.

The Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves, carved in the 1st century BCE by King Kharavela of the Mahameghavahana dynasty, served as residential and meditative retreats for Jain monks and feature the famous Hathigumpha inscription detailing the kingâ€™s reign.

These caves are of immense historical and religious importance, showcasing early Jain art, rock-cut architecture, and the cultural richness of ancient Kalinga.

Today, they are preserved as heritage monuments and attract pilgrims, historians, and tourists as a symbol of Odishaâ€™s spiritual and archaeological legacy.

A wonderful blend of history and nature! Visited Udayagiri Caves with family and kids â€” the ancient rock-cut caves were fascinating and full of stories. The carvings are beautiful, and the peaceful surroundings made it a perfect spot for a relaxed and educational outing. Great place for kids to explore and learn!

The caves are an absolute historical wonder. The way they are cut and sculpted is mesmerizing. Children under 15 yrs are free and it's 25per person. The udayagiri caves have less climbing but Khandagiri you have to climb a lot of stairs we didn't go to Khandagiri. It's recommended to come in the morning as it's very hot at noon. It has a ramp to get to one of the top parts of the caves .

1. Itâ€™s an archaeological and historical site. Entry ticket is only â‚¹20.
2. There are a total of 18 ancient caves, mainly used by Jain ascetics.
3. It's a nice and peaceful place to visit for history lovers. The site is divided into two hills: Udayagiri and Khandagiri, and both can be visited with a single ticket.
4. Thereâ€™s a beautiful temple located on top of Khandagiri hill.
5. A great place for learning history, taking photos, and enjoying light trekking.

It was a lovely experience. I went there with my mom and sister. Going up to the hill tops was pretty exhausting but we had fun. Then view from Khandgiri top was just amazingðŸ˜  The temple on Udaygiri was beautiful too. You will enjoy the hiking part inspite of hard hiking. Shere are budget friendly shops at the bottom of those hills where you can get food of drinks at regular price.
Ticket prices were Rs.25 per Indian person, and 300 per person for foreigners only.
If you have severe injury in legs or joint pain then avoid these. Because even the stairs are too steep.

Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves are amazing historical sites with beautiful carvings and ancient caves. The place is peaceful and great for exploring, offering a fantastic city view from the top. The caves have Jain heritage and rich history, making them a must-visit for history lovers. Entry tickets are affordable, and the area is clean and well-maintained. Monkeys roam around, so be careful with food. A great spot for photography and sightseeing!

placeMetadata.name: Nandankanan Zoological Park

sources.snippet: About 20 km away from Bhubaneswar by road, the Nandankanan Zoological Park (https://www.nandankanan.org/) is a popular attraction, especially for families with kids in tow. So to avoid long queues at the ticket counters during winter and school holidays, book online (https://www.nandankanan.org/tickets/). The Park, also home to the State Botanical Garden, is open on all days except Mondays; April to September, it is open between 7.30 am 5.30 pm while October to March, it is open from 8am to 5pm.
sources.shortName: Top Five Places To Visit In Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: At a distance of 17 km from Bhubaneswar Railway Station, Nandankanan Zoological Park is a zoo and botanical garden lies in the vicinity of Kanjia Lake in Bhubaneswar. It is one of the biggest and largest zoo parks in India and also one of the famous Bhubaneswar Tourist Places.Spread over an area of 400 hectares, Nandankanan was established in 1960 and declared as a sanctuary and zoo in 1979. It became the first zoo in India to join World Association of Zoos and Aquariums in 2009.
sources.shortName: 23 Best Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: Located 20 kilometers away from Bhubaneswar, Nandankanan Zoological Park is a zoo set up amidst the forest of Chandaka. Established in 1960 as a bastion of white tigers the zoo was converted into a natural reserve upon the recommendation of National Geographical Magazine. Stretching over an area of 4.37 sq km, the park offers a natural habitat to the rare species of flora and fauna.
sources.shortName: 23 Best Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: Spread across a massive area of 990 acres, the Nandankanan Zoological Park contains a zoo and a botanical park. It was inaugurated in 1979 and contains portions of the Chandaka Forests and Kanjia Lake. The Zoo contains several rare and endangered species such as White Tigers, Asiatic Lions, Crocodiles, Indian Pangolin and 34 aquariums that contains several species of fish.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Attractions In Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: Located amidst lush greenery and beautiful scenery, Nandankanan Zoological Park is a one of a kind pre-wedding photography location. Couples can shoot romantic moments against exotic wildlife, peaceful lakes and lush forests. The parkâ€™s unique flora and fauna offers creative and never seen before photography opportunities.
sources.shortName: Best 7 Pre-Wedding Photoshoot Places in Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: The Nandankanan Zoological Park is one of the premier zoos in India, making it one of the most interesting Places to visit in Bhubaneshwar. The zoo is set in a completely natural environment, built right within a forest. The zoo offers multiple entertainment facilities like lion safari, boating and cable car.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar, Tourist Places & Attractions

sources.snippet: Constructed with a goal to protect and preserve the flora and fauna of the habitat, the Nandankanan Zoological Park is a gorgeous sanctuary that is worth a visit in Bhubaneswar. Want to indulge in some wildlife photography?. See, now is your chance at making the most of your trip to Bhubaneswar.
sources.shortName: 10 Tourist Places in Bhubaneswar

sources.snippet: Credits: Dreamodisha, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons. It is one of the very first zoos opened in India. There are a total of 3004 species, including mammals, birds, reptiles and amphibians at Nandankanan Zoological Park.
sources.shortName: 47 Best Tourist Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar 2024

sources.snippet: It ranks as one of the biggest botanical gardens in India, area wise. It is also known to be a famous tourist spot in the city. This zoo came into limelight when it officially became the first zoo in the country to enter the World Association of Zoos and Aquariums in 2009.
sources.shortName: 7 Best Places to visit in Bhubaneswar

placeMetadata.description: Zoo with 1,500+ animals, including white tigers & pangolins, plus a botanical garden & scenic lake.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nandankanan Zoological Park, located in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, is a sprawling 437-hectare zoo and botanical garden established in 1960. It's home to over 1,500 animals including white tigers and pangolins. The park offers various attractions such as boating, safaris featuring white tigers, lions, bears and herbivores, a reptile park, zoo museum, orchid house and an aquarium.
placeMetadata.address: Bhubaneswar, Odisha 754005, India

reviews.reviewText:
My recent zoo visit was both enjoyable and educational. The variety of animals was impressive, including lions, giraffes, and playful monkeys. The enclosures were clean and well-maintained, offering good views without disturbing the animals. Informative signs taught me interesting facts about each species. The staff was friendly and eager to answer questions. Overall, it was a delightful experience, perfect for families and anyone interested in wildlife.
Adventure activity like boatingðŸš¤,zip liningðŸšˆ,Toy trainðŸš†are also available.

Nandankanan is a top recommendation for anyone who loves wildlife and nature. It's not just a great spot for families, but also a standout zoo in India due to its strong focus on conservation and its beautiful natural setting. While a few small tweaks to maintenance and crowd management could make the experience even better, its unique qualities make it a must-see destination.
* Timings: The park is open from 7:30 AM to 5:30 PM from April to September and from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM from October to March. Please note, it is closed on Mondays.

Just visited Nandankanan Zoological Park recently, and honestly, I had a really good time here. The zoo is pretty big and well maintained. Loved the greenery all around â€“ it gives such a calm and refreshing vibe ðŸŒ¿

Got to see so many animals up close, especially the white tiger, which was amazing! ðŸ¯ The safari was also a great experience â€“ felt exciting to see animals roaming freely in that area. Definitely something different from the usual zoo experience.

Itâ€™s a great spot to spend time with family or friends. Thereâ€™s boating too if youâ€™re into that kind of chill vibe ðŸš£â€â™‚ï¸

Overall, Iâ€™d totally recommend this place if youâ€™re in or around Bhubaneswar. Worth the visit ðŸ‘

Nandankanan Zoological Park, nestled 10â€¯km from Bhubaneswar, spans a lush 437â€¯hectares combining zoo, botanical garden, and wildlife sanctuary. Home to 157 species and over 3,500 animals including rare white tigers, gharials, and pangolins itâ€™s Indiaâ€™s first WAZA-accredited zoo.

Entry is â‚¹50 for adults, â‚¹10 for children, and â‚¹100 for foreigners. Safaris (lion, white tiger, bear, herbivore) cost â‚¹30/â‚¹15, while paddle-boat rides range from â‚¹50 to â‚¹150. A toy train and battery vehicles are also available, though small boat and safari queues occur during peak times. We paid 1500 for 3 people all with guide. It's take 3 -3.5 hrs entire park. Later depends upon you how much you spend.

Visit early morning (7:30â€¯AM) or late afternoon for optimal wildlife viewing; winters (Octâ€“Mar) are best.
The park is well-maintained, clean, and family-friendly, with a botanical garden, aquarium, library, and picnic spots.
However, avoid hiring overpriced guides many reviews advise self-guided exploration or using the battery vehicle to comfortably cover the large grounds. Overall, Nandankanan offers an enriching, educational, and enjoyable experience for wildlife lovers.

A huge and a wonderful Zoo. They have golf cart to cover zoo. They have attractions like cable car over the lake, boating, etc. over and above zoo and aviary. They have sections of apes, carnivores, reptiles, aquarium, etc. Huge space and lot of animals to enjoy. Even likes of Giraffe, Hippopotamus, elephants, Gibbons, etc. They also have White tiger and tiger cubs. It's worth visit especially if you have kids with you.

I had a fantastic time visiting Nandankanan Zoological Park! The entry ticket is very reasonably priced at just â‚¹50 per person, and it's absolutely worth every rupee for the experience you get. One of the highlights of the visit was taking the Pack Auto Taxi Tour, which costs â‚¹800 per head. It provides a comfortable and informative guided tour around the vast park areaâ€”perfect if you're visiting with family or prefer not to walk the entire distance.

The zoo is home to a diverse range of animals and birds. I saw majestic white tigers, lions, leopards, elephants, rhinoceroses, giraffes, zebras, crocodiles, and hippopotamuses. For bird lovers, there's an impressive aviary with species like peacocks, parrots, hornbills, emus, ostriches, and many more colorful and exotic birds.

The zoo is clean, well-maintained, and the animals appear to be well cared for. There's ample space, shaded areas to rest, and food stalls for snacks and refreshments. Also, the adjoining botanical garden and lake add to the scenic beauty of the place.

Highly recommended for a day out with friends or family, especially if you're a nature or wildlife enthusiast. Can't wait to visit again!

Nandankanan Zoo is so well-maintained and full of different animals and birds.
This is the perfect place for a family outing. The greenery, cleanliness, and arrangements are excellent.
I really enjoyed the visit!

We have walked for 6hours to cover the entire place.Very beautiful place. Everyone should visit. Environment is nice. Much much better than Alipore zoo. From station you will get government bus 13 number. Or you can take auto reserve.

placeMetadata.name: Chausathi Yogini Temple

sources.snippet: Located about 15km away by road from Bhubaneswar, the 64 Yogini Temple dates back to the early ninth century. The architecture of this temple is rather different from the popular Kalinga school of architecture. Carved into the inner wall of the circular temple are 64 niches; all except one contain a richly sculpted image of a Yogini (goddess) each.
