sources.snippet: One of the four Chausath Yogini Temples in the country, the temple at Hirapur is situated on the bank of Bhargavi River. Built-in the 9th century by Queen Hiradevi of the Bhauma dynasty the temple is also known as the Mahamaya Temple.

reviews.reviewText: The Chausathi Yogini Temple is a breathtaking historical gem that truly leaves a lasting impression. Nestled amidst serene surroundings, the temple showcases extraordinary architectural brilliance with its circular design and intricate carvings. Each of the 64 Yogini idols reflects exquisite craftsmanship and evokes a sense of spiritual tranquility. The panoramic views from the temple are mesmerizing, adding to its charm and making it a must-visit destination. A perfect blend of history, spirituality, and beauty, this temple is a treasure for heritage lovers and travelers alike!

The 36 Yogini Temple in Hirapur, located about 15 km from Bhubaneswar, is a unique and serene heritage site known for its circular, open-air structure and tantric significance. Built in the 9th century, the temple originally housed 64 Yogini idols, though only around 36 remain today, giving it its popular name. The intricate stone carvings, peaceful surroundings, and spiritual aura make it a fascinating spot for history enthusiasts and those seeking quiet reflection. Though not grand in size, the temple's distinct architecture and mystical charm leave a lasting impression. However, facilities around the site are minimal, so itâ€™s best visited as part of a short, well-planned heritage outing.

One of the oldest goddess  shrines of odisha built around 10th Century CE. Here you will find the great goddess Mahamaya's presence surrounded by 64 yoginis( Her sevikas). The environment and atmosphere was quite and serene. Must visit during spring or winter season.
The temple itself is not huge in area so you can just get around in 5 min. It holds historical significance. The river viewpoints near this temple are also something that you should consider

A mesmerizing historical gem just outside Bhubaneswar! The Chausath Yogini Temple in Hirapur is a rare 9th-century circular shrine, dedicated to 64 divine Yoginisâ€”feminine energies of Tantra. Its open-air, roofless design instantly sets it apart from other temples, creating a serene, mystical atmosphere thatâ€™s perfect for quiet reflection and spiritual connection.

The intricate stone carvings and powerful goddess statues, many still beautifully preserved, echo the templeâ€™s profound heritage. Youâ€™ll notice each Yogini depicted in unique poses and expressions, symbolizing the diversity and strength of the feminine divine. The narrow, low entrance adds a sense of awe as you step into this sacred mandala.

Although modest in size, the templeâ€™s peaceful ambiance, artistry, and deeply rooted history make it a must-visit for anyone interested in Odishaâ€™s unique cultural and spiritual legacy. The entire site is well-maintained, and its aura feels far removed from the noise of the city. Highly recommended for seekers of art, history, or tranquil places to meditate and feel inspired by ancient wisdom.

Yogini Temple in Hirapur, Odisha (also called the Mahamaya Temple), a rare and evocative example of hypaethral (open-air) tantric architecture from the 9th century CE. Situated about 20â€¯km south of Bhubaneswar, this circular temple is one of only four surviving 64 yogini shrines in India

Dedicated to the Cult of the Yoginisâ€”64 powerful female deities associated with Goddess Durga/Mahamaya and tantric practices involving worship of the five elements (bhumandala)

Found in the rural village of Hirapur, beyond Bhubaneswarâ€”best reached by taxi or private car  ï¿¼.

placeMetadata.name: Ananta Vasudeva Temple

sources.snippet: At a distance of 4.5 km from Bhubaneswar Railway Station, Ananta Vasudeva Temple is a famous Hindu Temple located on the eastern bank of Bindu Sarovar in Bhubaneswar. Situated near Lingaraja Temple, Ananta Vasudeva Temple is one of the few Vaishnavite temples in Bhubaneswar and also one of the top Bhubaneswar Tourist Places.Dating back to 13th century AD, Ananta Vasudeva Temple is the worship place of the complete idols of Lord Krishna, Lord Balarama and Goddess Subhadra. According to the legends, Lord Vishnu was worshiped at the place where Ananta Vasudeva Temple stands at present.
sources.shortName: 23 Best Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: Built by Queen Chandrika, the temple houses idols of Lord Balarama, Lord Kirshna, and Subhadra. This temple is the only one in Bhubaneshwar where Subhadra can be seen holding a pot of lotus and jewels in her hands while Lord Krishna can be seen holding a conch, a lotus and a Chakra in his hand. The statue of Lord Balarama stands under a serpent with seven heads.
sources.shortName: 30 Places to Visit in Bhubaneswar, Tourist Places & Attractions

sources.snippet: Legend has it that the early inhabitants worshiped the original image of Vishnu at the spot where this temple is built. The exterior of the temple is similar to the Lingaraj temple; the difference, of course, is that it is dedicated to Lord Vishnu instead.

It was renovated in the late 17th century by the Marathas.

reviews.reviewText: A spiritually enriching experience! Ananta Vasudeva Temple is one of the rare temples in Bhubaneswar dedicated to Lord Vishnu. The architecture is stunning, similar to the Lingaraj Temple, but with beautiful Vaishnavite carvings. The temple's traditional kitchen serves delicious Mahaprasad, cooked in earthen pots â€” a must-try! A peaceful and divine place that blends devotion, history, and culture perfectly.

Ancient temple dedicated to lord Krushna in the old toen area of Bhubaneshwar. It has beautiful carvings all around. As there is active worshipping in the temple, I felt some sections are not being cared for enough. It is in need of proper maintenance snd cleanliness.

Nestled amidst the cultural heartland of Odisha, this historic temple stands as a timeless testimony to the regionâ€™s rich architectural and spiritual heritage. Carved intricately from stone, the temple reflects the unmatched craftsmanship of ancient artisans. Every wall, pillar, and sculpture speaks a silent story from centuries past, showcasing depictions of gods, celestial beings, animals, and mythological scenes with breathtaking detail and symmetry.

The templeâ€™s towering spire reaches towards the sky, symbolizing a bridge between the earth and the divine. As sunlight falls upon its surfaces, the carvings come alive with shadows and light, creating a magical atmosphere that enchants every visitor. The structure is not just a place of worship, but also a remarkable example of engineering and design from an era where tools were limited but imagination was boundless.

Surrounded by natural beauty and calmness, the temple complex often fills with the soft sounds of bells, chants, and the fragrance of incense. Pilgrims and tourists alike are drawn to its aura â€” seeking blessings, inner peace, or simply to witness the marvel of its existence. The spiritual energy around it is powerful, yet deeply comforting.

Despite the passage of time, the temple remains well-preserved, echoing the glory of a bygone civilization that valued devotion, art, and architectural excellence. Whether one is religious or not, standing in the shadow of this grand monument stirs a deep respect for history and heritage. It is a living relic of faith, devotion, and timeless cultural pride.

Ananta Vasudeva Temple  is a Hindu temple dedicated to Krishna, an avatar of Vishnu located in Bhubaneswar close to Lingraj Temple and infront of Bindusagar .

The temple was constructed in the thirteenth century, and the complete murtis of Krishna, Balarama and Subhadra are worshipped there.

The temple dates back to the period of Chandrika Devi, the daughter of Anangabhima III of Eastern Ganga ruler, during the reign of the king Bhanudeva.

Ananta Basudev Mandir is a beautiful and peaceful temple, rich in history and architecture. Itâ€™s one of the few temples in Bhubaneswar dedicated to Lord Vishnu, located near the sacred Bindu Sagar. Ananta Basudev temple is one of the historical temple of Odisha built in 11th century AD. Lord Krishna, Balram and Devi Subhadra are worshipped in the temple. Temple structure is just amazing. You can get delicious Prasad (Abadha) here.

Located in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, the Ananta Basudev Temple is a rare and beautiful shrine dedicated to Lord Vishnu, locally known as Basudev.
The architecture reflects classic Kalinga style, and the peaceful surroundings make it a serene spiritual stop. The temple is also known for the sacred Anna Prasad (temple food) prepared in traditional earthen pots.

Krishna, an avatar of Vishnu, is worshipped in the Ananta Vasudeva Temple, a Hindu temple located in Bhubaneswar.  It is in front of Bindusagar and next to the Lingraj Temple in Odisha.

A Wonderful and Peaceful Escape!
This park is truly an amazing and peaceful place! It's a perfect retreat from the hustle and bustle of city life, offering immense tranquility. The lush greenery and vibrant flowers all around create a serene atmosphere, making it an ideal spot to spend some time close to nature. If you're looking for peace and beauty, this park is an excellent choice.
A beautiful park to spend your peaceful momment with your friends, family ,and also for couples

ðŸŒ³ Biju Patnaik Park, Bhubaneswar â€“ A Green Escape for All Ages! ðŸŒŸ

Located in the heart of Bhubaneswar, Biju Patnaik Park is a serene and well-maintained urban oasis that caters equally to children, adults, and fitness enthusiasts. Spread over a vast area, the park is a tribute to the legendary leader Biju Patnaik and reflects the city's commitment to green and inclusive public spaces.

Biju Patnaik Park, located in the heart of Bhubaneswar, is a sprawling 23-acre urban oasis dedicated to the memory of the former Chief Minister of Odisha, Biju Patnaik. Originally known as Forest Park, it was renamed in his honor and a statue of him stands in the middle of the park.
This popular recreational space offers a refreshing escape with its expansive green spaces, manicured gardens, vibrant rosaries, and picturesque rockeries. Fitness enthusiasts can enjoy the jogging tracks (clay, tiled, and concrete) and an open-air gym. There's also a dedicated children's play area with various equipment.
Key attractions include three serene water bodies, a musical fountain, and activity centers. The park is a favorite among locals for morning walks, yoga sessions, and evening relaxation. It's a family-friendly destination with ample space for picnics and leisure.
Open from 4:00 AM to 12:00 PM and again from 3:00 PM to 9:00 PM, with no entry fee, Biju Patnaik Park is a significant green lung in the city, offering a peaceful retreat for all.

Thank you

â€œTo the Sky He Belongedâ€

Diers to Adair, so were we â€”
Hearts that rose when skies werenâ€™t free,
But greater still, a name we knew:
Biju, the brave â€” the storm he flew.

With wings of steel and soul of flame,
He bore the weight, he bore the name
Of freedomâ€™s cry and dutyâ€™s call,
He soared where others feared to fall.

A lionheart in times unkind,
A fearless torch for humankind,
Not just a man, but Odishaâ€™s sun,
A dreamer, doer â€” our only one.

Diers to Adair? We understand:
For legends live in every land.
But he â€” he made the stars his own,
In skies of blue, his light is shown.

So now we stand, though time has flown,
With courage carved into our bone,
And whisper still with heads held high:
â€œTo Biju, who dared to touch the sky.â€

placeMetadata.name: Regional Museum of Natural History

sources.snippet: At a distance of 5 km from Bhubaneswar Railway Station, Regional Museum of Natural History is a famous museum located near Acharaya Vihar Square on Sachivalaya Marg, Bhubaneswar. reviews.reviewText:
Visiting the Regional Museum of Natural History, Bhubaneswar was a great experience! The museum is well-organized and has amazing displays about nature, wildlife, and tribal life. One of the best parts is the life-size animal models, which make you feel like you're in a real jungle.

The museum has sections on different animals, birds, marine life, and even fossils. Seeing dinosaur fossils up close was really exciting! The tribal section teaches about how local communities live in harmony with nature. Everything is presented in a simple and interesting way, so both kids and adults can enjoy it.

What I loved the most was how interactive and educational the museum is. There are plenty of things to learn, and itâ€™s a great place for school trips and families. Plus, the best partâ€”itâ€™s completely free! The museum is well-maintained, and the staff is friendly.

If you are in Bhubaneswar and love nature or wildlife, this place is a must-visit. Itâ€™s a peaceful and informative place where you can spend a couple of hours exploring and learning. Highly recommended for nature lovers, students, and anyone curious about the world around us!

I really enjoyed my visit to the Regional Museum of Natural History. The exhibits are not only informative but also beautifully arranged. I was especially impressed by the fossil section and the life-size animal models â€” they truly bring nature to life. It's a peaceful and inspiring place, perfect for a weekend visit with family or friends. Highly recommended.
Absolute delight to tour this museum. There are so many things for a curious mind in this museum. Definitely a must visit place if you are planning a vacation in Bhubaneswar

Wonderful Summer Camp Experience at RMNH, Bhubaneswar

The recent 7-day Summer Camp organized by RMNH, Bhubaneswar was an exceptional and enriching experience for children across Odisha. Students from various schools were invited to take part in this well-structured and thoughtfully curated program.

From day one, the camp was filled with excitement and learning. The organizers did a fantastic job of balancing educational activities with creative and recreational ones. Children engaged in sessions on wildlife and environmental awareness, participated in art, dance, and music, and even went on two educational picnics that brought learning to life in a fun and interactive way.

The RMNH team showed incredible dedication, ensuring that every child felt cared for, engaged, and inspired. The camp concluded on June 5, aligning beautifully with World Environment Day, with a special valedictory program, where students were awarded certificates recognizing their active involvement and achievements during the summer program week.

A big thank you to the entire team at RMNH, Bhubaneswar for creating such a memorable and impactful experience. I truly hope my kids get the opportunity to be a part of this incredible camp again next year!!

This museum is located in the middle of the city, (Bhubaneswar) next to the Pathani Samanta Planetarium (acharya bihar). There is a beautiful garden at the entrance of the museum where there are many kinds of flowers. No tickets are charged here, you can watch it for free.
In the museum, the bodies of many animals, birds and reptiles are kept in a safe condition after their death. There are skeletons of a giant whale, a rhino and a tusked elephant on display. Various types of butterflies and snakes have also been kept. You can also increase your knowledge by seeing many types of stones, minerals and stones.

Odisha Regional Museum, located near Pathani Samanta Planetarium, is a treasure of history, nature, and culture. It features a botanical garden designed for the visually impaired, a vivarium, and interactive activities that make it fun for kids too. One of the highlights is the animal skeleton section and preserved reptiles like cobras, which draw curiosity and wonder. Itâ€™s a great spot for students, families, and knowledge seekers to explore Odishaâ€™s diverse natural and cultural heritage.
Regional Museum Bhubaneswar, just next to Pathani Samanta Planetarium, is a beautiful place to have an idea about biodiversity. Free to visit, no ticket is  needed.

The Regional Museum of Natural History in Bhubaneswar is an engaging and educational destination that offers a fascinating insight into the natural world. Established in 2004, the museum serves as an excellent platform for learning about the regionâ€™s rich biodiversity, geology, and cultural heritage. Spread across multiple galleries, the exhibits showcase a variety of specimens, including preserved plants, fossils, and taxidermy animals, providing visitors with a deeper understanding of wildlife and ecosystems.

One of the museumâ€™s highlights is the life-sized diorama of animals in their natural habitats, which captivates both children and adults alike. The skeletons of marine creatures and fossils of prehistoric animals draw special attention, offering a glimpse into the ancient past. Additionally, there are sections dedicated to marine life and forests of Odisha, emphasizing conservation and environmental awareness.

The museum is well-maintained, with interactive displays and informative panels that make learning enjoyable. Its serene surroundings, complemented by a beautifully landscaped garden, provide a peaceful environment for visitors. Admission is free, making it accessible to everyone, including school groups and families.

Whether you're a nature enthusiast, a student, or a curious traveler, the Regional Museum of Natural History is a must-visit attraction in Bhubaneswar for an enriching and memorable experience.

Historical Significance & Architecture

Bhaskareswar Temple is an ancient Shiva temple known for its unique architectural style and historical importance. Built during the 7thâ€“8th century AD, the temple reflects the Kalinga style of architecture, characterized by intricate carvings and a towering structure. One of its most fascinating aspects is the presence of a massive Shiva Lingam, which is among the tallest in India. The lingam is believed to have mythological and spiritual significance, attracting devotees and history enthusiasts alike.

Religious & Spiritual Experience

The temple offers a peaceful and spiritual atmosphere, making it a great place for meditation and worship. Devotees visit throughout the year, with special crowds during Mahashivratri and Shravan Maas. The temple rituals and aarti create a divine aura, adding to the overall experience. Unlike many crowded temples, Bhaskareswar provides a serene space for deep spiritual connection.

Surroundings & Accessibility

Located in Bhubaneswar, the temple is easily accessible by road and public transport. It is surrounded by other historical temples, making it an excellent stop for those exploring the ancient heritage of the city. The temple complex is well-maintained, though some areas could benefit from better preservation efforts.

Final Verdict

Bhaskareswar Temple is a hidden gem for history lovers, devotees, and architecture enthusiasts. Its towering Shiva Lingam and tranquil setting make it a must-visit in Bhubaneswar. Whether you're seeking spiritual peace or a glimpse into Odishaâ€™s rich history, this temple is worth exploring.

The museum is well-maintained, with informative displays and peaceful surroundings. A perfect place for history and culture lovers. Highly recommended!

The Odisha State Tribal Museum is a must-visit for history lovers, students, and culture enthusiasts. It beautifully preserves and presents the diverse tribal heritage of Odisha. Whether you're a tourist or a local, this place offers a meaningful and enriching experience.

The Odisha Tribal Museum in Bhubaneswar is a cultural gem that beautifully showcases the rich heritage of Odishaâ€™s 62 tribal communities.
From traditional houses, weapons, musical instruments, and attire to daily lifestyle artifacts every corner reflects the vibrant essence of tribal life.

An absolute gem in the heart of Bhubaneswar! The Odisha State Tribal Museum offers a deep and fascinating glimpse into the lives, traditions, and cultures of the state's diverse tribal communities. From life size tribal hut replicas to beautifully curated galleries showcasing traditional tools, ornaments, textiles, and rituals everything is thoughtfully presented.

The museum is clean, well organized, and surprisingly peaceful. I especially appreciated the interactive exhibits and the audio visual sections that bring the tribal stories to life. The herbal garden and outdoor sculptures are a bonus if you love nature and quiet corners.

Whether you're a student, tourist, or just curious about Odishaâ€™s indigenous roots, this place is a must visit. Hats off to the efforts in preserving and celebrating such a rich cultural legacy!

The Dhauli Shanti Stupa, located near Bhubaneswar in Odisha, holds great historical and spiritual significance. It is believed to be the site of the Kalinga War (261 BCE), where Emperor Ashoka witnessed massive bloodshed that changed his heart. Deeply moved, Ashoka renounced violence and embraced Buddhism, spreading messages of peace and compassion. The Japanese Buddhist Sangha later built the white Peace Pagoda (Shanti Stupa) here in 1972, symbolizing harmony and non-violence. Surrounded by ancient rock edicts of Ashoka and serene landscapes, Dhauli Shanti Stupa stands as a reminder of transformation, peace, and the universal message of brotherhood.

Experience: Not much to explore, but it is a peaceful and pleasant place to visit. The four statues of Buddha each depict a story. I am not sure if private vehicles are allowed near the temple, as we traveled there on a small government bus.

The four Buddha statues at Dhauli Shanti Stupa (Peace Pagoda), Odisha represent the four significant stages of Lord Buddhaâ€™s life. Each statue is placed facing one direction of the stupa, symbolizing peace and compassion:

Birth of Buddha (Lumbini) â€“ Depicts the moment of Siddhartha Gautamaâ€™s birth.

Enlightenment (Bodh Gaya) â€“ Represents Buddha attaining enlightenment under the Bodhi tree.

First Sermon (Sarnath) â€“ Symbolizes the "Dharmachakra Pravartan" (Turning of the Wheel of Dharma) when he first taught the path.

Mahaparinirvana (Kushinagar) â€“ Depicts Buddhaâ€™s final departure from the world, symbolizing eternal peace.

These statues together narrate Buddhaâ€™s journey and convey the message of non-violence, compassion, and universal peace.

A peaceful and spiritual place with stunning views and historical significance. The white stupa, surrounded by greenery, offers a calm and serene atmosphere. From the top, you can enjoy a panoramic view of the surrounding area, including parts of the city and the Daya River. There's no entry fee, and a good parking space is available nearby. A must-visit spot near Puri for those interested in history, Buddhism, or just a quiet break from the city.

It's located in a hilly area. Peaceful and calm. The statue area is marbled. Enough space for sitting around,relaxing. Ample car parking space. Small shops with souvenirs available. Lift for senior citizens was not working. People with knee problems can avoid climbing up.

Dhauli Shanti Stupa â€“ A Peaceful Gem Just Outside Bhubaneswar

Tucked atop a quiet hill on the outskirts of Bhubaneswar, the Dhauli Shanti Stupa is a little slice of serenity. The moment you step up to it, thereâ€™s a real sense of calm in the air - something about the white domed structure against the sky just puts your heart at ease.

The stupa itself is a beauty - gracefully built, with stunning carvings and elegant depictions of Lord Buddha in various postures. You donâ€™t have to be deeply spiritual to feel the stillness of the place. Itâ€™s peaceful in a way that makes you want to just sit, take a breath, and let the world slow down a bit.

From the top, you get a sweeping view of the Daya River flowing gently through the landscape - absolutely cracking at sunset, when the whole place is bathed in gold. Mind you, in the heat of the afternoon, it can get a bit much, especially since shoes have to come off - so aim for an evening visit if you can.

Itâ€™s free to enter, easy to reach by car, and honestly, itâ€™s well worth the short drive out from the city. Whether youâ€™re into history, architecture, or just fancy a peaceful moment with a view, Dhauliâ€™s a spot thatâ€™ll stay with you.

The Pathani Samanta Planetarium in Bhubaneswar offers an enriching experience for anyone interested in astronomy and space. The planetarium is a testament to the dedication of its team, presenting an impressive array of videos about the sky and space. These shows, played in Odia, Hindi, and English, cater to a diverse audience with four different timings to choose from. The informative and engaging content provides a fascinating glimpse into the wonders of the universe, making it a fantastic educational outing for both adults and children. The ticket prices are quite reasonable, with adults paying 30 rupees and children under 15 paying just 20 rupees. However, the experience was somewhat marred by the fact that half of the screen was not functioning during the show. This technical issue detracted from the overall immersive experience and was a disappointment considering the otherwise high quality of the presentations. Despite this setback, the planetarium remains a valuable resource for learning and exploration. The affordability and the range of languages offered make it accessible to a broad audience, but it is hoped that the screen issue will be addressed soon to enhance the viewing experience further. Overall, it is a commendable effort that provides significant educational value to its visitors.

The Brahmeswar Temple in Bhubaneswar is a masterpiece of Kalinga architecture, standing as a testament to Odishaâ€™s rich heritage. Built in 1058 CE by Kolavati Devi, the mother of Somavamsi king Udyotakesari, this temple marks an important transition in temple design, showcasing intricate craftsmanship and artistic excellence.

Carved out of sandstone, the temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and features breathtaking sculptures of celestial dancers, musicians, and mythological figures. The introduction of iron beams in construction and the first use of surasundaris (heavenly maidens) on temple walls make it a significant milestone in temple architecture.

Surrounded by smaller shrines, Brahmeswar Templeâ€™s sanctum enshrines a powerful Shiva Lingam, drawing devotees and history lovers alike. The templeâ€™s rekha deul (curvilinear spire) and the exquisite nagara-style carvings tell stories of devotion, art, and cultural grandeur. Even after nearly a thousand years, it remains a serene and spiritual landmark in Bhubaneswar, the City of Temples.

The Brahmeshwar Temple, located in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, is a 9th-century temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. Built in Kalinga-style architecture, it features an elaborate rekha deula (tower) and intricate carvings of divine figures, musicians, and dancers. The temple marks the transition to more elaborate Odishan temple designs, influencing later structures like Lingaraj Temple. The presence of tantric symbols suggests tantric worship was practiced here. Surrounded by smaller shrines, it holds deep religious and historical significance. Situated about 10 km from the city center, it is easily accessible by taxis, auto-rickshaws, and local buses, making it a must-visit heritage site.

Nestled in Nayapalli, Bhubaneswar, Ekamra Kananâ€”also known as the RPRC Botanical Gardenâ€”is a refreshing escape into natureâ€™s embrace. Spanning an impressive 487â€“500 acres, this verdant haven is managed by the Regional Plant Resource Centre and has been a city landmark since its founding in 1985  ï¿¼.

As you wander through its diverse landscapes, you encounter several distinct zones. The highlight is the Cactus Garden, covering around 100 acres, featuring over 1,000 succulent and cactus varieties in a striking pyramid-style glasshouse  ï¿¼. Nearby, themed flower gardensâ€”scented flowers, hibiscus, and a vast rose gardenâ€”showcase hundreds of plant species, enhancing both your senses and Instagram feed  ï¿¼.

A serene 40-acre artificial lake lies at the heart of the garden. Visitors can enjoy & simply admire the migratory birdlife, especially during winter  ï¿¼. A nearby birdwatching tower offers panoramic views of the lake and surrounding greenery  ï¿¼.

Families love the childrenâ€™s play zone with swings, slides, and a musical fountainâ€”sure to delight younger guests  ï¿¼. Natural walking trails, built for morning and evening fitness routines, thread through woodland scenery, connecting visitors with the adjacent Chandaka forest  ï¿¼.

Amenities bolster the visitor experience: thoughtful walking trails (3â€¯km), well-kept benches, restrooms, drinking water stations, and on-site stalls offering local handicrafts and light refreshments  ï¿¼. The parkâ€™s popularity surges during the annual January flower show, a vibrant showcase of horticultural skills .

reviews.reviewText: Dhaulagiri rock edict of Emperor Ashoka is one of the best preserved rock edicts in India. It dates back to the 2nd century and carry's a message of peace and brotherhood to the world. The elephant carved on the rock is one of the earliest Buddhist architecture in Odisha.

The Ashokan Rock edict at Dhauli is located very close to the Shanti Stupa and is an iconic piece of history dating to the 3rd century BC. Ashoka's edict are one of the greatest sources of information on life during the Mauryan period. There are two important structures here, one is the actual massive rock edict and the second is a rock carved elephant. The rock edict contains information about the laws that Ashoka implemented in Kalinga which he conquered post a bloody battle. The semi carved body of the elephant is supposed to represent Buddha. Do not miss this spot!

Ashokan Rock edict is a very very historical place near dhauli. There's rock where The great Ashoka inscribed in ancient text which is preserved by ASI. The whole place is maintained by ASI. Beautiful garden, a big banyan tree. A beautiful place to visit.

It remains hot and crowdy during public holidays but you have many shops to chill, just be prepared and and enjoy the great place to connect to our glorious history!

We found two sleeping GUARDS and one local young guy chatting over phone having no idea about this place.

ðŸ˜¡ðŸ˜¡ðŸ˜¡

The first ever Ashokan Rock Edict is here in this place.   It is carved on a rock panel in Pali and Prakruti languages.  The panel is below an elephant head carved out of that rock in the top side.  The people are using this as a picnic spot without realising the importance of the place. The translation of the edicts in vernacular Hindi and English is available in the place itself.
These are mainly talking about non violence and protection of women.  Fortunately the rock edicts are well preserved from vagaries of nature by a steel panel case.  To approach the hill top steps are there and the place is well maintained.  When we went it was raining and drizzling alternatively and hence the climate was too good to enjoy the beauty of this 2nd century AD masterpiece in tact.

Indian artÂ consists of a variety of art forms, includingÂ painting,Â sculpture,Â pottery, andÂ textile artsÂ such asÂ woven silk. Geographically, it spans the entireÂ Indian subcontinent, including what is nowÂ India,Â Pakistan,Â Bangladesh,Â Sri Lanka,Â Nepal,Â BhutanÂ and easternÂ Afghanistan. A strong sense of design is characteristic of Indian art and can be observed in its modern and traditional forms.
The origin of Indian art can be traced toÂ pre-historicÂ settlements in the 3rd millennium BC. On its way to modern times, Indian art has had cultural influences, as well as religious influences such asÂ Hinduism,Â Buddhism,Â Jainism,Â SikhismÂ andÂ Islam. In spite of this complex mixture of religious traditions, generally, the prevailing artistic style at any time and place has been shared by the major religious groups.
In historic art, sculpture in stone and metal, mainly religious, has survived the Indian climate better than other media and provides most of the best remains. Many of the most important ancient finds that are not in carved stone come from the surrounding, drier regions rather than India itself.Â Indian funeralÂ and philosophic traditions excludeÂ grave goods, which is the main source of ancient art in other cultures.
Indian artist styles historically followedÂ Indian religionsÂ out of the subcontinent, having an especially large influence inÂ Tibet,Â South East AsiaÂ andÂ China. Indian art has itself received influences at times, especially fromÂ Central AsiaÂ andÂ Iran, and Europe.

reviews.reviewText: A serene and spiritually uplifting place! The temple's architecture is captivating, featuring towering spires visible from various parts of the city. The idols of Lord Rama, Goddess Sita, and Lord Lakshmana are beautifully adorned. The evening aarti, accompanied by traditional musical instruments, creates a deeply devotional atmosphere. The well-maintained gardens offer a peaceful space for reflection. A must-visit for those seeking tranquility and spiritual enrichment in Bhubaneswar.

Shri Ram Mandir, located in Ekamra Vihar, Bhubaneswar, is a revered spiritual site housing idols of Shri Ram, Laxman, Maa Sita, and Lord Hanuman.

The temple experiences a significant influx of devotees during Rama Navami, making it a vibrant center of religious celebration.

It also features a Kalyana Mandap, where wedding ceremonies are performed with sacred rituals.

Entry to the temple is completely free of charge, making it accessible to all devotees.

Visitors can conveniently park their vehicles around the boundary of the temple premises.

The temple sees peak footfall from November to April, drawing both local worshippers and tourists.

"Its images appear under 'Ram Mandir' located in Jharapada on Google Maps, so don't get confused."

Baitala Deula, located in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, is an 8th-century temple dedicated to Goddess Chamunda (Shakti). It is renowned for its unique Khakara-style architecture, a variation of the Kalinga temple style, featuring a curved, rectangular tower (shikhara) resembling Buddhist chaityas. The templeâ€™s intricate carvings depict Hindu deities, tantric symbols, and mythological figures. Inside, the three-headed Chamunda idol, seated on a corpse with symbolic elements, reflects tantric influences. Situated near Lingaraj Temple, it is easily accessible by road, taxis, and local transport. Baitala Deula stands as an important monument for its architectural, religious, and tantric significance in Odishaâ€™s heritage.

A fascinating piece of Odishaâ€™s ancient heritage, Baital Temple (locally known as Tinimundia Temple) is a hidden gem in Bhubaneswar. Its unique triple sanctum (three spires) architecture, which gives it the name "Tinimundia," stands out from other temples in the city. Dedicated to Goddess Chamunda, the temple is known for its tantric influences and rich carvings on stone. Though relatively less crowded, it carries immense historical and spiritual significance. The atmosphere is peaceful, and itâ€™s a great place to witness the Kalinga style of temple architecture up close. Worth a visit for history buffs and spiritual seekers alike!

A small but beautiful temple located bang in the middle of a busy street in the city. It's based on a fusion of two architectural styles - Oriya & South Indian - and so looks somewhat different from the other temples in Bhubaneswar. Very few people visit this place because it's located quite off the usual tourist route but it's worth the detour.

A small temple but such a mind blowing architecture. You will love if you ae an art lovers. It is a few minutes walk from lingaraj temple and Bindu Sagar lake. No ticket is required and its not crowded even at weekends.

Vaitala Deula temple is dedicated to GoddessÂ Chamundi & isÂ located in the Old Town of Bhubaneswar. It is also known asÂ Tini-mundia deula due to the three spires on top of it, which is a very distinct feature of the temple. The three spires are believed to represent the three powers of the Goddess Mother, Chamunda - Mahasaraswati, Mahalakshmi and Mahakali. The presiding deity Chamunda sits on a corpse flanked by a jackal and an owl and is decorated with a garland of skulls. She holds a snake, bow, shield, sword, trident, thunderbolt and an arrow, and is piercing the neck of the demon.  The temple is very easy to be missed. It's not as well known as the Lingaraj Temple or Parashurameshwara Temple or Mukteswara Temple. Also, almost adjoining the temple are residential houses. Perhaps, Archaeological Survey of India should strictly enforce it's laws & ensure ancient monuments are protected, & an important aspect to that is to secure the lands in the immediate vicinity of a monument & protecting it from encroachment. Along with other great temples in the Old Town, this temple also has to be promoted.
Witness this beautiful 8th century temple. A unique architectural marvel, the peak of kalinga architectural brilliance. A time-capsule into the 8th century.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Khandagiri, located in the Indian state of Odisha, is a historical and cultural site that boasts ancient rock-cut caves and inscriptions. These caves are believed to date back to the 2nd century BCE and were carved out for Jain monks. The site offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape and provides insight into the region's rich history. Visitors can explore the intricately carved caves, adorned with ornate carvings and sculptures, while learning about their significance from local guides.

placeMetadata.name: Dhauli Hills

sources.snippet: Located at the banks of the Daya River, the Dhauli hill is considered to be the place where the ancient Kalinga war took place. The edicts of Ashoka describing the ancient war can also be found here along with a rock-cut elephant. After the Kalinga war, King Ashoka was moved by the bloodshed and adopted the teachings of Buddhism and non-violence.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Attractions In Bhubaneswar

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Dhauli Hills, located in Bhubaneswar, is a popular tourist destination known for its breathtaking panoramic views of the city and surrounding countryside. The hills offer a challenging yet rewarding trekking experience with steep slopes leading to the top. This historical site is home to the Shanti Stupa, built by Japanese people as a symbol of peace and tranquility. Visitors can explore rock edicts of Emperor Ashoka, reflecting the area's rich heritage and spiritual significance.

The Shanti Stupa at Dhauli Hills is a significant symbol of love and peace. This place is a significant Buddhist pilgrimage center -  this is the place where King Ashoka resigned from violent wars. He fought one of the most vicious and bloody wars with King of Kalinga and adopted the path of Dharma and Peace after seeing the death of thousands of soldiers here.
The river Daya flows close to this hill.
The top of the hill provides a unique and picturesque view of the Bhubaneswar city. There is ample parking area. They charge an entry fee of Rs.40 from 4 wheeler vehicles, not sure of 2 wheeler vehicles.
There are a lot of small shops near the hill that sell souvenirs and food items.
The light and music show at Dhauli (see my photo uploads) is by far the best that I have seen. The show gives a glimpse of the lives of the kings of the Mourya empire and specifically focuses on the Kalinga war that transformed King Ashoka from a warrior to a peace loving king
A must visit place in Bhubaneswar.

The place holds deep historical and spiritual significance, being linked to Emperor Ashokaâ€™s transformation after the Kalinga War. The peace pagoda (Shanti Stupa) stands majestically against the sky, and the white dome structure with intricate carvings makes it a perfect backdrop for photos.

Surrounded by lush greenery and calm vibes, itâ€™s a great place to reflect, relax, and soak in both history and beauty. Whether you're into photography, heritage, or just looking for a quiet escape, Dhauli Hills is well worth the visit.

reviews.reviewText:
Mukteswar Temple in Bhubaneswar is truly a marvel of ancient architecture and spirituality. Nestled in the heart of the city, this temple stands out with its intricate carvings and stunning design, which are a testament to the craftsmanship of the 10th century. The moment you step into the temple complex, you are transported back in time, surrounded by the serene and sacred ambiance.

The templeâ€™s unique blend of Buddhist, Jain, and Hindu architectural styles makes it one of its kind. The detailed sculptures and the iconic torana (arched gateway) are simply breathtaking. The lush gardens surrounding the temple add to its charm, providing a peaceful retreat from the hustle and bustle of city life.

Whether you are a history enthusiast, a spiritual seeker, or simply someone who appreciates beauty, Mukteswar Temple is a must-visit. The temple is well-maintained, and the local guides are knowledgeable, offering fascinating insights into its rich history and significance.

Overall, Mukteswar Temple is a hidden gem that deserves all the praise. Donâ€™t miss the chance to experience this architectural wonder!

you will observe the peaceful mind if you spend sitting and praying. The east faced main temple of it is surrounded by four subsidiary temples.

All the greenery and the yellow blooming flowers were adding so much charm to the ethereal beauty of the temple. A must visit for sure. Itâ€™s located in the same compound of Lingaraj Temple.

It is small temple complex located next to the northern side of Lingaraja temple. The complex is well maintained and you will observe the peaceful mind if you spend sitting and praying. The east faced main temple of Chitrakarini ( a form of Devi Saraswathi) is surrounded by four subsidiary temples.

Chitrakarini Temple is located approximately 75m east of Papanasini Temple Complex on Rath Road in Bhubaneswar, right next to northern Lingaraja Temple compound wall. The east-facing temple is built in the panchayatana layout, with a central main temple accompanied by four smaller subsidiary shrines. The temples are set within a pretty and well manicured garden that is maintained by the ASI. North lintel frieze of Jagamohana window depicting Krishna playing his flute amidst enchanted followers and listening cattle
The temple is thought to have been constructed around the middle of the 13th century A.D. This potentially suggests it could have been instigated by the Ganga dynasty king Narasingha Deva I (also known as Parama Mahesvara) who reigned over the kingdom of Kalinga (ancient Odisha) between circa 1238 and 1264 A.D. This is the same ruler who is attributed as the builder of the Sun Temple at Konark. The templeâ€™s name is derived from the Goddess Chitrakarini, a Sanskrit term that roughly translates to â€œPaintressâ€. She is a form of the Goddess Saraswati, who is regarded as the prime goddess of knowledge and creative expression.

The Chitreswar temple, otherwise known as Chitrakarini is situated to the North of the Lingaraj temple within a close distance. It has four smaller temples in the four corners of the compound. It is a saptaratha temple and is one of the most beautifully decorated monuments. Within the sanctum a chamunda image is worshipped.

reviews.reviewText: RS Wedding Bells perfectly captured the essence of our wedding! Their candid shots were simply stunning, bringing out every emotion and beautiful detail. The team was professional, creative, and made us feel comfortable throughout. Highly recommend them for anyone looking to relive their special moments through heartfelt photography!

Surya and his team are highly professional people who keep upgrading themselves in this competitive market. They're the classiest most aesthetically pleasing photographers based in Bhubaneswar. Their prices are also reasonable compared to market. I would recommend them without even a second thought!

Surya and Team, such a splendid work! Your photography truly captured the best moments of our Big day! Your candid video graphs are priceless treasures that we will cherish forever! Thank you for your professionalism, creativity, and attention to detail. We couldn't be happier with the results! Good luck!

My wedding was on dec 2022 and one thing I was very particular about was the photography so I started searching months ahead. Luckily I found these guys and trust me they are the best. Extremely polite, always before time and highly accommodating. I am bad at posing so I explained them how I want my pics and videos more candid, people having fun and they have captured all the fun moments amazingly well. From photos to videos to my photo album everything is perfect. My entire family now love their work. Surprisingly the photos and videos were delivered way faster then I imagined..Thanks to the entire team :)

As we journeyed through the magical moments of our wedding and itâ€™s beautiful ceremonies, there were two artists behind the lens who brilliantly captured every tear, every laugh, and every heartfelt embrace. RS Wedding Bellsâ€™s talented photographer and cinematographer, deserve an overflowing measure of gratitude and applause.

From the first click to the final frame, RS Wedding Bells skillfully navigated the delicate balance between being observers and becoming a part of our celebration. With an eye for detail that only true artists possess, they immortalized not just the staged moments but the candid, unscripted snippets of joy that we will cherish forever.

Each photograph is a brushstroke in the canvas of our shared life. The candid shots remind us of the unguarded laughter that echoed through the venue, while the meticulously composed portraits freeze in time the emotions etched across our faces. Through their lens, we see the love in our eyes, the warmth in our embraces, and the happiness that radiated from every corner of the celebrations.

But RS Wedding Bells did not stop at photographs alone. Their cinematography brought our day to life, capturing the movement, the voices, and the laughter that paint the complete picture of our wedding. Their diligent editing has given us a cinematic masterpiece that encapsulates the essence of our day, from the smallest details to the grandest gestures.

In the quiet corners and the bustling dance floor, RS Wedding Bells were there, capturing memories without disrupting the flow of events. Their dedication and professionalism shone through, making us feel at ease even during the most hectic moments. Their passion for their craft was evident as they searched for the perfect angle, the ideal lighting, and the fleeting expressions that define who we are as a couple.

Today, as we reflect upon the pages of our wedding album and watch our wedding video, we're struck by the power of these images and footage. They evoke not just the scenes but the emotions, taking us back to that day in all its glory. RS Wedding Bells' work has given us the gift of reliving our wedding, not just as a mental recollection, but as a visual and auditory masterpiece that touches the heart.

So, to RS Wedding Bells, we extend our deepest gratitude. Thank you for your artistry, your dedication, and your patience. Thank you for capturing the essence of our love and weaving a story through images and film that we'll share with generations to come. Your work is a treasure that will forever remain a cherished part of our journey, and for that, we are truly grateful.

With heartfelt thanks,
Ayushi & Abhishek

ops.insert: Elaborately carved cave dwellings dating to the 1st c. BCE, topped by an 18th-c. CE Jain temple.
Zoo with 1,500+ animals, including white tigers & pangolins, plus a botanical garden & scenic lake.
Roofless, round 9th-century temple with over 50 carvings of goddess-like figures known as yoginis.
Sprawling city park featuring expansive green spaces, manicured gardens, playgrounds & trails.
Prominent 13th-century Hindu temple featuring idols of Lord Krishna, Balarama & Subhadra.
Museum with a botanical garden for the visually impaired, a vivarium & hands-on activities for kids.
Striking white peace pagoda & Buddhist shrine constructed atop Dhauli Hill in 1972.
Museum displaying tribal costumes, jewelry, art, household objects, musical instruments & more.
Astronomical displays are cast onto the roof of this modernistic government-run planetarium.
Flanked by 4 smaller shrines, this centuries-old sandstone temple is famed for its ornate carvings.
Outdoor amusement park with old-fashioned rides, plus a water park & a 10-pin bowling alley.
Landscaped park with a rose garden, cactus collection, musical fountain & a lake with paddle boats.
Hindu temple devoted to Lord Krishna featuring a garden & a lotus-shaped shrine, plus an eatery.
Iconic Hindu temple with an ornate facade & statues of Lord Rama, Lord Lakshman & Goddess Sita.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally weâ€™re always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Bhubaneswar, the capital city of Odisha, is a treasure trove of stunning architecture, lush greenery, and rich cultural heritage. From the intricate carvings of ancient temples to the serene landscapes of its parks, this city offers countless opportunities for capturing breathtaking photographs. Whether you're wandering through the historic lanes or exploring the vibrant local markets, every corner of Bhubaneswar tells a story waiting to be immortalized through your lens.

As you embark on your photographic journey, you'll discover a delightful mix of iconic landmarks and hidden gems. The majestic Lingaraj Temple, with its towering spires, and the tranquil Dhauli Shanti Stupa, perched atop a hill, are just a few of the must-visit spots that showcase the city's unique charm. The Wanderlog team is passionate about uncovering these picturesque locations, from the bustling Biju Patnaik Park to the artistic displays at the Odisha Modern Art Gallery. So grab your camera and get ready to explore the best photo spots that Bhubaneswar has to offer!
